35 namespace alglib_impl
36 {
37 typedef struct
38 {
39  ae_int_t n;
40  ae_int_t nx;
41  ae_int_t d;
42  double r;
43  ae_int_t nw;
44  kdtree tree;
45  ae_int_t modeltype;
46  ae_matrix q;
47  ae_vector xbuf;
48  ae_vector tbuf;
49  ae_vector rbuf;
50  ae_matrix xybuf;
51  ae_int_t debugsolverfailures;
52  double debugworstrcond;
53  double debugbestrcond;
54 } idwinterpolant;
55 typedef struct
56 {
57  ae_int_t n;
58  double sy;
59  ae_vector x;
60  ae_vector y;
61  ae_vector w;
62 } barycentricinterpolant;
63 typedef struct
64 {
65  ae_bool periodic;
66  ae_int_t n;
67  ae_int_t k;
68  ae_int_t continuity;
69  ae_vector x;
70  ae_vector c;
71 } spline1dinterpolant;

73 {

75  double rmserror;
76  double avgerror;
77  double avgrelerror;
78  double maxerror;
79 } polynomialfitreport;

114 {

157  double repavgrelerror;
158  double repmaxerror;

165  rcommstate rstate;

185 {
186  ae_int_t ny;
187  ae_int_t nx;

203  double epsort;
204  double epserr;
205  ae_int_t maxits;
206  double h;

208  ae_matrix x;
209  ae_matrix y;
210  ae_vector calcbufxcx;
211  ae_matrix calcbufx;
212  ae_vector calcbuftags;
213 } rbfmodel;

215 {
216  ae_int_t arows;
217  ae_int_t acols;
218  ae_int_t annz;
219  ae_int_t iterationscount;
220  ae_int_t nmv;
221  ae_int_t terminationtype;
222 } rbfreport;

224 {
225  ae_int_t k;
226  ae_int_t stype;
227  ae_int_t n;
228  ae_int_t m;
229  ae_int_t d;
230  ae_vector x;
231  ae_vector y;
232  ae_vector f;
233 } spline2dinterpolant;

258 /*************************************************************************
259 IDW interpolant.
260 *************************************************************************/
261 class _idwinterpolant_owner
262 {
263 public:
264  _idwinterpolant_owner();
265  _idwinterpolant_owner(const _idwinterpolant_owner &rhs);
266  _idwinterpolant_owner& operator=(const _idwinterpolant_owner &rhs);
267  virtual ~_idwinterpolant_owner();
268  alglib_impl::idwinterpolant* c_ptr();
269  alglib_impl::idwinterpolant* c_ptr() const;
270 protected:
271  alglib_impl::idwinterpolant *p_struct;
272 };

275 public:

278  idwinterpolant& operator=(const idwinterpolant &rhs);
279  virtual ~idwinterpolant();
280 
281 };

335 /*************************************************************************
336 Polynomial fitting report:
337  TaskRCond reciprocal of task's condition number
338  RMSError RMS error
339  AvgError average error
340  AvgRelError average relative error (for non-zero Y[I])
341  MaxError maximum error
342 *************************************************************************/
343 class _polynomialfitreport_owner
344 {
345 public:
346  _polynomialfitreport_owner();
347  _polynomialfitreport_owner(const _polynomialfitreport_owner &rhs);
348  _polynomialfitreport_owner& operator=(const _polynomialfitreport_owner &rhs);
349  virtual ~_polynomialfitreport_owner();
350  alglib_impl::polynomialfitreport* c_ptr();
351  alglib_impl::polynomialfitreport* c_ptr() const;
352 protected:
353  alglib_impl::polynomialfitreport *p_struct;
354 };
355 class polynomialfitreport : public _polynomialfitreport_owner
356 {
357 public:
358  polynomialfitreport();
359  polynomialfitreport(const polynomialfitreport &rhs);
360  polynomialfitreport& operator=(const polynomialfitreport &rhs);
361  virtual ~polynomialfitreport();
362  double &taskrcond;
363  double &rmserror;
364  double &avgerror;
365  double &avgrelerror;
366  double &maxerror;
367 
368 };

378 *************************************************************************/

408 /*************************************************************************
409 Spline fitting report:
410  RMSError RMS error
411  AvgError average error
412  AvgRelError average relative error (for non-zero Y[I])
413  MaxError maximum error
414 
415 Fields below are filled by obsolete functions (Spline1DFitCubic,
416 Spline1DFitHermite). Modern fitting functions do NOT fill these fields:
417  TaskRCond reciprocal of task's condition number
418 *************************************************************************/
419 class _spline1dfitreport_owner
420 {
421 public:
422  _spline1dfitreport_owner();
423  _spline1dfitreport_owner(const _spline1dfitreport_owner &rhs);
424  _spline1dfitreport_owner& operator=(const _spline1dfitreport_owner &rhs);
425  virtual ~_spline1dfitreport_owner();
426  alglib_impl::spline1dfitreport* c_ptr();
427  alglib_impl::spline1dfitreport* c_ptr() const;
428 protected:
429  alglib_impl::spline1dfitreport *p_struct;
430 };
431 class spline1dfitreport : public _spline1dfitreport_owner
432 {
433 public:
434  spline1dfitreport();
435  spline1dfitreport(const spline1dfitreport &rhs);
436  spline1dfitreport& operator=(const spline1dfitreport &rhs);
437  virtual ~spline1dfitreport();
438  double &taskrcond;
439  double &rmserror;
440  double &avgerror;
441  double &avgrelerror;
442  double &maxerror;
443 
444 };
445 
446 
447 /*************************************************************************
448 Least squares fitting report. This structure contains informational fields
449 which are set by fitting functions provided by this unit.
450 
451 Different functions initialize different sets of fields, so you should
452 read documentation on specific function you used in order to know which
453 fields are initialized.
454 
455  TaskRCond reciprocal of task's condition number
456  IterationsCount number of internal iterations
457 
458  VarIdx if user-supplied gradient contains errors which were
459  detected by nonlinear fitter, this field is set to
460  index of the first component of gradient which is
461  suspected to be spoiled by bugs.
462 
463  RMSError RMS error
464  AvgError average error
465  AvgRelError average relative error (for non-zero Y[I])
466  MaxError maximum error
467 
468  WRMSError weighted RMS error
469 
470  CovPar covariance matrix for parameters, filled by some solvers
471  ErrPar vector of errors in parameters, filled by some solvers
472  ErrCurve vector of fit errors - variability of the best-fit
473  curve, filled by some solvers.
474  Noise vector of per-point noise estimates, filled by
475  some solvers.
476  R2 coefficient of determination (non-weighted, non-adjusted),
477  filled by some solvers.
478 *************************************************************************/
479 class _lsfitreport_owner
480 {
481 public:
482  _lsfitreport_owner();
483  _lsfitreport_owner(const _lsfitreport_owner &rhs);
484  _lsfitreport_owner& operator=(const _lsfitreport_owner &rhs);
485  virtual ~_lsfitreport_owner();
486  alglib_impl::lsfitreport* c_ptr();
487  alglib_impl::lsfitreport* c_ptr() const;
488 protected:
489  alglib_impl::lsfitreport *p_struct;
490 };
491 class lsfitreport : public _lsfitreport_owner
492 {
493 public:
494  lsfitreport();
495  lsfitreport(const lsfitreport &rhs);
496  lsfitreport& operator=(const lsfitreport &rhs);
497  virtual ~lsfitreport();
498  double &taskrcond;
499  ae_int_t &iterationscount;
500  ae_int_t &varidx;
501  double &rmserror;
502  double &avgerror;
503  double &avgrelerror;
504  double &maxerror;
505  double &wrmserror;
506  real_2d_array covpar;
507  real_1d_array errpar;
508  real_1d_array errcurve;
509  real_1d_array noise;
510  double &r2;
511 
512 };
513

515 /*************************************************************************
516 Nonlinear fitter.
517 
518 You should use ALGLIB functions to work with fitter.
519 Never try to access its fields directly!
520 *************************************************************************/
521 class _lsfitstate_owner
522 {
523 public:
524  _lsfitstate_owner();
525  _lsfitstate_owner(const _lsfitstate_owner &rhs);
526  _lsfitstate_owner& operator=(const _lsfitstate_owner &rhs);
527  virtual ~_lsfitstate_owner();
528  alglib_impl::lsfitstate* c_ptr();
529  alglib_impl::lsfitstate* c_ptr() const;
530 protected:
531  alglib_impl::lsfitstate *p_struct;
532 };

534 {

550 };

552 /*************************************************************************

554 
555 You should not try to access its members directly - use PSpline2XXXXXXXX()
556 functions instead.
557 *************************************************************************/

559 {
560 public:

563  _pspline2interpolant_owner& operator=(const _pspline2interpolant_owner &rhs);
564  virtual ~_pspline2interpolant_owner();
565  alglib_impl::pspline2interpolant* c_ptr();

567 protected:
568  alglib_impl::pspline2interpolant *p_struct;
569 };

609 /*************************************************************************
610 RBF model.
611 
612 Never try to directly work with fields of this object - always use ALGLIB
613 functions to use this object.
614 *************************************************************************/

616 {
617 public:

620  _rbfmodel_owner& operator=(const _rbfmodel_owner &rhs);
621  virtual ~_rbfmodel_owner();
622  alglib_impl::rbfmodel* c_ptr();
623  alglib_impl::rbfmodel* c_ptr() const;
624 protected:
625  alglib_impl::rbfmodel *p_struct;
626 };

633  virtual ~rbfmodel();

635 };

638 /*************************************************************************
639 RBF solution report:
640 * TerminationType - termination type, positive values - success,
641  non-positive - failure.
642 *************************************************************************/
643 class _rbfreport_owner
644 {
645 public:
646  _rbfreport_owner();
647  _rbfreport_owner(const _rbfreport_owner &rhs);
648  _rbfreport_owner& operator=(const _rbfreport_owner &rhs);
649  virtual ~_rbfreport_owner();
650  alglib_impl::rbfreport* c_ptr();
651  alglib_impl::rbfreport* c_ptr() const;
652 protected:
653  alglib_impl::rbfreport *p_struct;
654 };
655 class rbfreport : public _rbfreport_owner
656 {
657 public:
658  rbfreport();
659  rbfreport(const rbfreport &rhs);
660  rbfreport& operator=(const rbfreport &rhs);
661  virtual ~rbfreport();
662  ae_int_t &arows;
663  ae_int_t &acols;
664  ae_int_t &annz;
665  ae_int_t &iterationscount;
666  ae_int_t &nmv;
667  ae_int_t &terminationtype;
668 
669 };

696 /*************************************************************************
697 3-dimensional spline inteprolant
698 *************************************************************************/
699 class _spline3dinterpolant_owner
700 {
701 public:
702  _spline3dinterpolant_owner();
703  _spline3dinterpolant_owner(const _spline3dinterpolant_owner &rhs);
704  _spline3dinterpolant_owner& operator=(const _spline3dinterpolant_owner &rhs);
705  virtual ~_spline3dinterpolant_owner();
706  alglib_impl::spline3dinterpolant* c_ptr();
707  alglib_impl::spline3dinterpolant* c_ptr() const;
708 protected:
709  alglib_impl::spline3dinterpolant *p_struct;
710 };
711 class spline3dinterpolant : public _spline3dinterpolant_owner
712 {
713 public:
714  spline3dinterpolant();
715  spline3dinterpolant(const spline3dinterpolant &rhs);
716  spline3dinterpolant& operator=(const spline3dinterpolant &rhs);
717  virtual ~spline3dinterpolant();
718 
719 };
720 
721 /*************************************************************************
722 IDW interpolation
723 
724 INPUT PARAMETERS:
725  Z - IDW interpolant built with one of model building
726  subroutines.
727  X - array[0..NX-1], interpolation point
728 
729 Result:
730  IDW interpolant Z(X)
731 
732  -- ALGLIB --
733  Copyright 02.03.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
734 *************************************************************************/
735 double idwcalc(const idwinterpolant &z, const real_1d_array &x);
736 
737 
738 /*************************************************************************
739 IDW interpolant using modified Shepard method for uniform point
740 distributions.
741 
742 INPUT PARAMETERS:
743  XY - X and Y values, array[0..N-1,0..NX].
744  First NX columns contain X-values, last column contain
745  Y-values.
746  N - number of nodes, N>0.
747  NX - space dimension, NX>=1.
748  D - nodal function type, either:
749  * 0 constant model. Just for demonstration only, worst
750  model ever.
751  * 1 linear model, least squares fitting. Simpe model for
752  datasets too small for quadratic models
753  * 2 quadratic model, least squares fitting. Best model
754  available (if your dataset is large enough).
755  * -1 "fast" linear model, use with caution!!! It is
756  significantly faster than linear/quadratic and better
757  than constant model. But it is less robust (especially
758  in the presence of noise).
759  NQ - number of points used to calculate nodal functions (ignored
760  for constant models). NQ should be LARGER than:
761  * max(1.5*(1+NX),2^NX+1) for linear model,
762  * max(3/4*(NX+2)*(NX+1),2^NX+1) for quadratic model.
763  Values less than this threshold will be silently increased.
764  NW - number of points used to calculate weights and to interpolate.
765  Required: >=2^NX+1, values less than this threshold will be
766  silently increased.
767  Recommended value: about 2*NQ
768 
769 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
770  Z - IDW interpolant.
771 
772 NOTES:
773  * best results are obtained with quadratic models, worst - with constant
774  models
775  * when N is large, NQ and NW must be significantly smaller than N both
776  to obtain optimal performance and to obtain optimal accuracy. In 2 or
777  3-dimensional tasks NQ=15 and NW=25 are good values to start with.
778  * NQ and NW may be greater than N. In such cases they will be
779  automatically decreased.
780  * this subroutine is always succeeds (as long as correct parameters are
781  passed).
782  * see 'Multivariate Interpolation of Large Sets of Scattered Data' by
783  Robert J. Renka for more information on this algorithm.
784  * this subroutine assumes that point distribution is uniform at the small
785  scales. If it isn't - for example, points are concentrated along
786  "lines", but "lines" distribution is uniform at the larger scale - then
787  you should use IDWBuildModifiedShepardR()
788 
789 
790  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
791  Copyright 02.03.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
792 *************************************************************************/
793 void idwbuildmodifiedshepard(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t nx, const ae_int_t d, const ae_int_t nq, const ae_int_t nw, idwinterpolant &z);
794 
795 
796 /*************************************************************************
797 IDW interpolant using modified Shepard method for non-uniform datasets.
798 
799 This type of model uses constant nodal functions and interpolates using
800 all nodes which are closer than user-specified radius R. It may be used
801 when points distribution is non-uniform at the small scale, but it is at
802 the distances as large as R.
803 
804 INPUT PARAMETERS:
805  XY - X and Y values, array[0..N-1,0..NX].
806  First NX columns contain X-values, last column contain
807  Y-values.
808  N - number of nodes, N>0.
809  NX - space dimension, NX>=1.
810  R - radius, R>0
811 
812 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
813  Z - IDW interpolant.
814 
815 NOTES:
816 * if there is less than IDWKMin points within R-ball, algorithm selects
817  IDWKMin closest ones, so that continuity properties of interpolant are
818  preserved even far from points.
819 
820  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
821  Copyright 11.04.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
822 *************************************************************************/
823 void idwbuildmodifiedshepardr(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t nx, const double r, idwinterpolant &z);
824 
825 
826 /*************************************************************************
827 IDW model for noisy data.
828 
829 This subroutine may be used to handle noisy data, i.e. data with noise in
830 OUTPUT values. It differs from IDWBuildModifiedShepard() in the following
831 aspects:
832 * nodal functions are not constrained to pass through nodes: Qi(xi)<>yi,
833  i.e. we have fitting instead of interpolation.
834 * weights which are used during least squares fitting stage are all equal
835  to 1.0 (independently of distance)
836 * "fast"-linear or constant nodal functions are not supported (either not
837  robust enough or too rigid)
838 
839 This problem require far more complex tuning than interpolation problems.
840 Below you can find some recommendations regarding this problem:
841 * focus on tuning NQ; it controls noise reduction. As for NW, you can just
842  make it equal to 2*NQ.
843 * you can use cross-validation to determine optimal NQ.
844 * optimal NQ is a result of complex tradeoff between noise level (more
845  noise = larger NQ required) and underlying function complexity (given
846  fixed N, larger NQ means smoothing of compex features in the data). For
847  example, NQ=N will reduce noise to the minimum level possible, but you
848  will end up with just constant/linear/quadratic (depending on D) least
849  squares model for the whole dataset.
850 
851 INPUT PARAMETERS:
852  XY - X and Y values, array[0..N-1,0..NX].
853  First NX columns contain X-values, last column contain
854  Y-values.
855  N - number of nodes, N>0.
856  NX - space dimension, NX>=1.
857  D - nodal function degree, either:
858  * 1 linear model, least squares fitting. Simpe model for
859  datasets too small for quadratic models (or for very
860  noisy problems).
861  * 2 quadratic model, least squares fitting. Best model
862  available (if your dataset is large enough).
863  NQ - number of points used to calculate nodal functions. NQ should
864  be significantly larger than 1.5 times the number of
865  coefficients in a nodal function to overcome effects of noise:
866  * larger than 1.5*(1+NX) for linear model,
867  * larger than 3/4*(NX+2)*(NX+1) for quadratic model.
868  Values less than this threshold will be silently increased.
869  NW - number of points used to calculate weights and to interpolate.
870  Required: >=2^NX+1, values less than this threshold will be
871  silently increased.
872  Recommended value: about 2*NQ or larger
873 
874 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
875  Z - IDW interpolant.
876 
877 NOTES:
878  * best results are obtained with quadratic models, linear models are not
879  recommended to use unless you are pretty sure that it is what you want
880  * this subroutine is always succeeds (as long as correct parameters are
881  passed).
882  * see 'Multivariate Interpolation of Large Sets of Scattered Data' by
883  Robert J. Renka for more information on this algorithm.
884 
885 
886  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
887  Copyright 02.03.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
888 *************************************************************************/
889 void idwbuildnoisy(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t nx, const ae_int_t d, const ae_int_t nq, const ae_int_t nw, idwinterpolant &z);
890 
891 /*************************************************************************
892 Rational interpolation using barycentric formula
893 
894 F(t) = SUM(i=0,n-1,w[i]*f[i]/(t-x[i])) / SUM(i=0,n-1,w[i]/(t-x[i]))
895 
896 Input parameters:
897  B - barycentric interpolant built with one of model building
898  subroutines.
899  T - interpolation point
900 
901 Result:
902  barycentric interpolant F(t)
903 
904  -- ALGLIB --
905  Copyright 17.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
906 *************************************************************************/
907 double barycentriccalc(const barycentricinterpolant &b, const double t);
908 
909 
910 /*************************************************************************
911 Differentiation of barycentric interpolant: first derivative.
912 
913 Algorithm used in this subroutine is very robust and should not fail until
914 provided with values too close to MaxRealNumber (usually MaxRealNumber/N
915 or greater will overflow).
916 
917 INPUT PARAMETERS:
918  B - barycentric interpolant built with one of model building
919  subroutines.
920  T - interpolation point
921 
922 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
923  F - barycentric interpolant at T
924  DF - first derivative
925 
926 NOTE
927 
928 
929  -- ALGLIB --
930  Copyright 17.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
931 *************************************************************************/
932 void barycentricdiff1(const barycentricinterpolant &b, const double t, double &f, double &df);
933 
934 
935 /*************************************************************************
936 Differentiation of barycentric interpolant: first/second derivatives.
937 
938 INPUT PARAMETERS:
939  B - barycentric interpolant built with one of model building
940  subroutines.
941  T - interpolation point
942 
943 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
944  F - barycentric interpolant at T
945  DF - first derivative
946  D2F - second derivative
947 
948 NOTE: this algorithm may fail due to overflow/underflor if used on data
949 whose values are close to MaxRealNumber or MinRealNumber. Use more robust
950 BarycentricDiff1() subroutine in such cases.
951 
952 
953  -- ALGLIB --
954  Copyright 17.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
955 *************************************************************************/
956 void barycentricdiff2(const barycentricinterpolant &b, const double t, double &f, double &df, double &d2f);
957 
958 
959 /*************************************************************************
960 This subroutine performs linear transformation of the argument.
961 
962 INPUT PARAMETERS:
963  B - rational interpolant in barycentric form
964  CA, CB - transformation coefficients: x = CA*t + CB
965 
966 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
967  B - transformed interpolant with X replaced by T
968 
969  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
970  Copyright 19.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
971 *************************************************************************/
972 void barycentriclintransx(const barycentricinterpolant &b, const double ca, const double cb);
973 
974 
975 /*************************************************************************
976 This subroutine performs linear transformation of the barycentric
977 interpolant.
978 
979 INPUT PARAMETERS:
980  B - rational interpolant in barycentric form
981  CA, CB - transformation coefficients: B2(x) = CA*B(x) + CB
982 
983 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
984  B - transformed interpolant
985 
986  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
987  Copyright 19.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
988 *************************************************************************/
989 void barycentriclintransy(const barycentricinterpolant &b, const double ca, const double cb);
990 
991 
992 /*************************************************************************
993 Extracts X/Y/W arrays from rational interpolant
994 
995 INPUT PARAMETERS:
996  B - barycentric interpolant
997 
998 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
999  N - nodes count, N>0
1000  X - interpolation nodes, array[0..N-1]
1001  F - function values, array[0..N-1]
1002  W - barycentric weights, array[0..N-1]
1003 
1004  -- ALGLIB --
1005  Copyright 17.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
1006 *************************************************************************/
1007 void barycentricunpack(const barycentricinterpolant &b, ae_int_t &n, real_1d_array &x, real_1d_array &y, real_1d_array &w);
1008 
1009 
1010 /*************************************************************************
1011 Rational interpolant from X/Y/W arrays
1012 
1013 F(t) = SUM(i=0,n-1,w[i]*f[i]/(t-x[i])) / SUM(i=0,n-1,w[i]/(t-x[i]))
1014 
1015 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1016  X - interpolation nodes, array[0..N-1]
1017  F - function values, array[0..N-1]
1018  W - barycentric weights, array[0..N-1]
1019  N - nodes count, N>0
1020 
1021 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
1022  B - barycentric interpolant built from (X, Y, W)
1023 
1024  -- ALGLIB --
1025  Copyright 17.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
1026 *************************************************************************/
1027 void barycentricbuildxyw(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &w, const ae_int_t n, barycentricinterpolant &b);
1028 
1029 
1030 /*************************************************************************
1031 Rational interpolant without poles
1032 
1033 The subroutine constructs the rational interpolating function without real
1034 poles (see 'Barycentric rational interpolation with no poles and high
1035 rates of approximation', Michael S. Floater. and Kai Hormann, for more
1036 information on this subject).
1037 
1038 Input parameters:
1039  X - interpolation nodes, array[0..N-1].
1040  Y - function values, array[0..N-1].
1041  N - number of nodes, N>0.
1042  D - order of the interpolation scheme, 0 <= D <= N-1.
1043  D<0 will cause an error.
1044  D>=N it will be replaced with D=N-1.
1045  if you don't know what D to choose, use small value about 3-5.
1046 
1047 Output parameters:
1048  B - barycentric interpolant.
1049 
1050 Note:
1051  this algorithm always succeeds and calculates the weights with close
1052  to machine precision.
1053 
1054  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
1055  Copyright 17.06.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
1056 *************************************************************************/
1057 void barycentricbuildfloaterhormann(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t d, barycentricinterpolant &b);
1058 
1059 /*************************************************************************
1060 Conversion from barycentric representation to Chebyshev basis.
1061 This function has O(N^2) complexity.
1062 
1063 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1064  P - polynomial in barycentric form
1065  A,B - base interval for Chebyshev polynomials (see below)
1066  A<>B
1067 
1068 OUTPUT PARAMETERS
1069  T - coefficients of Chebyshev representation;
1070  P(x) = sum { T[i]*Ti(2*(x-A)/(B-A)-1), i=0..N-1 },
1071  where Ti - I-th Chebyshev polynomial.
1072 
1073 NOTES:
1074  barycentric interpolant passed as P may be either polynomial obtained
1075  from polynomial interpolation/ fitting or rational function which is
1076  NOT polynomial. We can't distinguish between these two cases, and this
1077  algorithm just tries to work assuming that P IS a polynomial. If not,
1078  algorithm will return results, but they won't have any meaning.
1079 
1080  -- ALGLIB --
1081  Copyright 30.09.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
1082 *************************************************************************/
1083 void polynomialbar2cheb(const barycentricinterpolant &p, const double a, const double b, real_1d_array &t);
1084 
1085 
1086 /*************************************************************************
1087 Conversion from Chebyshev basis to barycentric representation.
1088 This function has O(N^2) complexity.
1089 
1090 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1091  T - coefficients of Chebyshev representation;
1092  P(x) = sum { T[i]*Ti(2*(x-A)/(B-A)-1), i=0..N },
1093  where Ti - I-th Chebyshev polynomial.
1094  N - number of coefficients:
1095  * if given, only leading N elements of T are used
1096  * if not given, automatically determined from size of T
1097  A,B - base interval for Chebyshev polynomials (see above)
1098  A<B
1099 
1100 OUTPUT PARAMETERS
1101  P - polynomial in barycentric form
1102 
1103  -- ALGLIB --
1104  Copyright 30.09.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
1105 *************************************************************************/
1106 void polynomialcheb2bar(const real_1d_array &t, const ae_int_t n, const double a, const double b, barycentricinterpolant &p);
1107 void polynomialcheb2bar(const real_1d_array &t, const double a, const double b, barycentricinterpolant &p);
1108 
1109 
1110 /*************************************************************************
1111 Conversion from barycentric representation to power basis.
1112 This function has O(N^2) complexity.
1113 
1114 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1115  P - polynomial in barycentric form
1116  C - offset (see below); 0.0 is used as default value.
1117  S - scale (see below); 1.0 is used as default value. S<>0.
1118 
1119 OUTPUT PARAMETERS
1120  A - coefficients, P(x) = sum { A[i]*((X-C)/S)^i, i=0..N-1 }
1121  N - number of coefficients (polynomial degree plus 1)
1122 
1123 NOTES:
1124 1. this function accepts offset and scale, which can be set to improve
1125  numerical properties of polynomial. For example, if P was obtained as
1126  result of interpolation on [-1,+1], you can set C=0 and S=1 and
1127  represent P as sum of 1, x, x^2, x^3 and so on. In most cases you it
1128  is exactly what you need.
1129 
1130  However, if your interpolation model was built on [999,1001], you will
1131  see significant growth of numerical errors when using {1, x, x^2, x^3}
1132  as basis. Representing P as sum of 1, (x-1000), (x-1000)^2, (x-1000)^3
1133  will be better option. Such representation can be obtained by using
1134  1000.0 as offset C and 1.0 as scale S.
1135 
1136 2. power basis is ill-conditioned and tricks described above can't solve
1137  this problem completely. This function will return coefficients in
1138  any case, but for N>8 they will become unreliable. However, N's
1139  less than 5 are pretty safe.
1140 
1141 3. barycentric interpolant passed as P may be either polynomial obtained
1142  from polynomial interpolation/ fitting or rational function which is
1143  NOT polynomial. We can't distinguish between these two cases, and this
1144  algorithm just tries to work assuming that P IS a polynomial. If not,
1145  algorithm will return results, but they won't have any meaning.
1146 
1147  -- ALGLIB --
1148  Copyright 30.09.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
1149 *************************************************************************/
1150 void polynomialbar2pow(const barycentricinterpolant &p, const double c, const double s, real_1d_array &a);
1151 void polynomialbar2pow(const barycentricinterpolant &p, real_1d_array &a);
1152 
1153 
1154 /*************************************************************************
1155 Conversion from power basis to barycentric representation.
1156 This function has O(N^2) complexity.
1157 
1158 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1159  A - coefficients, P(x) = sum { A[i]*((X-C)/S)^i, i=0..N-1 }
1160  N - number of coefficients (polynomial degree plus 1)
1161  * if given, only leading N elements of A are used
1162  * if not given, automatically determined from size of A
1163  C - offset (see below); 0.0 is used as default value.
1164  S - scale (see below); 1.0 is used as default value. S<>0.
1165 
1166 OUTPUT PARAMETERS
1167  P - polynomial in barycentric form
1168 
1169 
1170 NOTES:
1171 1. this function accepts offset and scale, which can be set to improve
1172  numerical properties of polynomial. For example, if you interpolate on
1173  [-1,+1], you can set C=0 and S=1 and convert from sum of 1, x, x^2,
1174  x^3 and so on. In most cases you it is exactly what you need.
1175 
1176  However, if your interpolation model was built on [999,1001], you will
1177  see significant growth of numerical errors when using {1, x, x^2, x^3}
1178  as input basis. Converting from sum of 1, (x-1000), (x-1000)^2,
1179  (x-1000)^3 will be better option (you have to specify 1000.0 as offset
1180  C and 1.0 as scale S).
1181 
1182 2. power basis is ill-conditioned and tricks described above can't solve
1183  this problem completely. This function will return barycentric model
1184  in any case, but for N>8 accuracy well degrade. However, N's less than
1185  5 are pretty safe.
1186 
1187  -- ALGLIB --
1188  Copyright 30.09.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
1189 *************************************************************************/
1190 void polynomialpow2bar(const real_1d_array &a, const ae_int_t n, const double c, const double s, barycentricinterpolant &p);
1191 void polynomialpow2bar(const real_1d_array &a, barycentricinterpolant &p);
1192 
1193 
1194 /*************************************************************************
1195 Lagrange intepolant: generation of the model on the general grid.
1196 This function has O(N^2) complexity.
1197 
1198 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1199  X - abscissas, array[0..N-1]
1200  Y - function values, array[0..N-1]
1201  N - number of points, N>=1
1202 
1203 OUTPUT PARAMETERS
1204  P - barycentric model which represents Lagrange interpolant
1205  (see ratint unit info and BarycentricCalc() description for
1206  more information).
1207 
1208  -- ALGLIB --
1209  Copyright 02.12.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
1210 *************************************************************************/
1211 void polynomialbuild(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, barycentricinterpolant &p);
1212 void polynomialbuild(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, barycentricinterpolant &p);
1213 
1214 
1215 /*************************************************************************
1216 Lagrange intepolant: generation of the model on equidistant grid.
1217 This function has O(N) complexity.
1218 
1219 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1220  A - left boundary of [A,B]
1221  B - right boundary of [A,B]
1222  Y - function values at the nodes, array[0..N-1]
1223  N - number of points, N>=1
1224  for N=1 a constant model is constructed.
1225 
1226 OUTPUT PARAMETERS
1227  P - barycentric model which represents Lagrange interpolant
1228  (see ratint unit info and BarycentricCalc() description for
1229  more information).
1230 
1231  -- ALGLIB --
1232  Copyright 03.12.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
1233 *************************************************************************/
1234 void polynomialbuildeqdist(const double a, const double b, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, barycentricinterpolant &p);
1235 void polynomialbuildeqdist(const double a, const double b, const real_1d_array &y, barycentricinterpolant &p);
1236 
1237 
1238 /*************************************************************************
1239 Lagrange intepolant on Chebyshev grid (first kind).
1240 This function has O(N) complexity.
1241 
1242 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1243  A - left boundary of [A,B]
1244  B - right boundary of [A,B]
1245  Y - function values at the nodes, array[0..N-1],
1246  Y[I] = Y(0.5*(B+A) + 0.5*(B-A)*Cos(PI*(2*i+1)/(2*n)))
1247  N - number of points, N>=1
1248  for N=1 a constant model is constructed.
1249 
1250 OUTPUT PARAMETERS
1251  P - barycentric model which represents Lagrange interpolant
1252  (see ratint unit info and BarycentricCalc() description for
1253  more information).
1254 
1255  -- ALGLIB --
1256  Copyright 03.12.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
1257 *************************************************************************/
1258 void polynomialbuildcheb1(const double a, const double b, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, barycentricinterpolant &p);
1259 void polynomialbuildcheb1(const double a, const double b, const real_1d_array &y, barycentricinterpolant &p);
1260 
1261 
1262 /*************************************************************************
1263 Lagrange intepolant on Chebyshev grid (second kind).
1264 This function has O(N) complexity.
1265 
1266 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1267  A - left boundary of [A,B]
1268  B - right boundary of [A,B]
1269  Y - function values at the nodes, array[0..N-1],
1270  Y[I] = Y(0.5*(B+A) + 0.5*(B-A)*Cos(PI*i/(n-1)))
1271  N - number of points, N>=1
1272  for N=1 a constant model is constructed.
1273 
1274 OUTPUT PARAMETERS
1275  P - barycentric model which represents Lagrange interpolant
1276  (see ratint unit info and BarycentricCalc() description for
1277  more information).
1278 
1279  -- ALGLIB --
1280  Copyright 03.12.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
1281 *************************************************************************/
1282 void polynomialbuildcheb2(const double a, const double b, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, barycentricinterpolant &p);
1283 void polynomialbuildcheb2(const double a, const double b, const real_1d_array &y, barycentricinterpolant &p);
1284 
1285 
1286 /*************************************************************************
1287 Fast equidistant polynomial interpolation function with O(N) complexity
1288 
1289 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1290  A - left boundary of [A,B]
1291  B - right boundary of [A,B]
1292  F - function values, array[0..N-1]
1293  N - number of points on equidistant grid, N>=1
1294  for N=1 a constant model is constructed.
1295  T - position where P(x) is calculated
1296 
1297 RESULT
1298  value of the Lagrange interpolant at T
1299 
1300 IMPORTANT
1301  this function provides fast interface which is not overflow-safe
1302  nor it is very precise.
1303  the best option is to use PolynomialBuildEqDist()/BarycentricCalc()
1304  subroutines unless you are pretty sure that your data will not result
1305  in overflow.
1306 
1307  -- ALGLIB --
1308  Copyright 02.12.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
1309 *************************************************************************/
1310 double polynomialcalceqdist(const double a, const double b, const real_1d_array &f, const ae_int_t n, const double t);
1311 double polynomialcalceqdist(const double a, const double b, const real_1d_array &f, const double t);
1312 
1313 
1314 /*************************************************************************
1315 Fast polynomial interpolation function on Chebyshev points (first kind)
1316 with O(N) complexity.
1317 
1318 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1319  A - left boundary of [A,B]
1320  B - right boundary of [A,B]
1321  F - function values, array[0..N-1]
1322  N - number of points on Chebyshev grid (first kind),
1323  X[i] = 0.5*(B+A) + 0.5*(B-A)*Cos(PI*(2*i+1)/(2*n))
1324  for N=1 a constant model is constructed.
1325  T - position where P(x) is calculated
1326 
1327 RESULT
1328  value of the Lagrange interpolant at T
1329 
1330 IMPORTANT
1331  this function provides fast interface which is not overflow-safe
1332  nor it is very precise.
1333  the best option is to use PolIntBuildCheb1()/BarycentricCalc()
1334  subroutines unless you are pretty sure that your data will not result
1335  in overflow.
1336 
1337  -- ALGLIB --
1338  Copyright 02.12.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
1339 *************************************************************************/
1340 double polynomialcalccheb1(const double a, const double b, const real_1d_array &f, const ae_int_t n, const double t);
1341 double polynomialcalccheb1(const double a, const double b, const real_1d_array &f, const double t);
1342 
1343 
1344 /*************************************************************************
1345 Fast polynomial interpolation function on Chebyshev points (second kind)
1346 with O(N) complexity.
1347 
1348 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1349  A - left boundary of [A,B]
1350  B - right boundary of [A,B]
1351  F - function values, array[0..N-1]
1352  N - number of points on Chebyshev grid (second kind),
1353  X[i] = 0.5*(B+A) + 0.5*(B-A)*Cos(PI*i/(n-1))
1354  for N=1 a constant model is constructed.
1355  T - position where P(x) is calculated
1356 
1357 RESULT
1358  value of the Lagrange interpolant at T
1359 
1360 IMPORTANT
1361  this function provides fast interface which is not overflow-safe
1362  nor it is very precise.
1363  the best option is to use PolIntBuildCheb2()/BarycentricCalc()
1364  subroutines unless you are pretty sure that your data will not result
1365  in overflow.
1366 
1367  -- ALGLIB --
1368  Copyright 02.12.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
1369 *************************************************************************/
1370 double polynomialcalccheb2(const double a, const double b, const real_1d_array &f, const ae_int_t n, const double t);
1371 double polynomialcalccheb2(const double a, const double b, const real_1d_array &f, const double t);
1372 
1373 /*************************************************************************
1374 This subroutine builds linear spline interpolant
1375 
1376 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1377  X - spline nodes, array[0..N-1]
1378  Y - function values, array[0..N-1]
1379  N - points count (optional):
1380  * N>=2
1381  * if given, only first N points are used to build spline
1382  * if not given, automatically detected from X/Y sizes
1383  (len(X) must be equal to len(Y))
1384 
1385 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
1386  C - spline interpolant
1387 
1388 
1389 ORDER OF POINTS
1390 
1391 Subroutine automatically sorts points, so caller may pass unsorted array.
1392 
1393  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
1394  Copyright 24.06.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
1395 *************************************************************************/
1396 void spline1dbuildlinear(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, spline1dinterpolant &c);
1397 void spline1dbuildlinear(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, spline1dinterpolant &c);
1398 
1399 
1400 /*************************************************************************
1401 This subroutine builds cubic spline interpolant.
1402 
1403 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1404  X - spline nodes, array[0..N-1].
1405  Y - function values, array[0..N-1].
1406 
1407 OPTIONAL PARAMETERS:
1408  N - points count:
1409  * N>=2
1410  * if given, only first N points are used to build spline
1411  * if not given, automatically detected from X/Y sizes
1412  (len(X) must be equal to len(Y))
1413  BoundLType - boundary condition type for the left boundary
1414  BoundL - left boundary condition (first or second derivative,
1415  depending on the BoundLType)
1416  BoundRType - boundary condition type for the right boundary
1417  BoundR - right boundary condition (first or second derivative,
1418  depending on the BoundRType)
1419 
1420 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
1421  C - spline interpolant
1422 
1423 ORDER OF POINTS
1424 
1425 Subroutine automatically sorts points, so caller may pass unsorted array.
1426 
1427 SETTING BOUNDARY VALUES:
1428 
1429 The BoundLType/BoundRType parameters can have the following values:
1430  * -1, which corresonds to the periodic (cyclic) boundary conditions.
1431  In this case:
1432  * both BoundLType and BoundRType must be equal to -1.
1433  * BoundL/BoundR are ignored
1434  * Y[last] is ignored (it is assumed to be equal to Y[first]).
1435  * 0, which corresponds to the parabolically terminated spline
1436  (BoundL and/or BoundR are ignored).
1437  * 1, which corresponds to the first derivative boundary condition
1438  * 2, which corresponds to the second derivative boundary condition
1439  * by default, BoundType=0 is used
1440 
1441 PROBLEMS WITH PERIODIC BOUNDARY CONDITIONS:
1442 
1443 Problems with periodic boundary conditions have Y[first_point]=Y[last_point].
1444 However, this subroutine doesn't require you to specify equal values for
1445 the first and last points - it automatically forces them to be equal by
1446 copying Y[first_point] (corresponds to the leftmost, minimal X[]) to
1447 Y[last_point]. However it is recommended to pass consistent values of Y[],
1448 i.e. to make Y[first_point]=Y[last_point].
1449 
1450  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
1451  Copyright 23.06.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
1452 *************************************************************************/
1453 void spline1dbuildcubic(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t boundltype, const double boundl, const ae_int_t boundrtype, const double boundr, spline1dinterpolant &c);
1454 void spline1dbuildcubic(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, spline1dinterpolant &c);
1455 
1456 
1457 /*************************************************************************
1458 This function solves following problem: given table y[] of function values
1459 at nodes x[], it calculates and returns table of function derivatives d[]
1460 (calculated at the same nodes x[]).
1461 
1462 This function yields same result as Spline1DBuildCubic() call followed by
1463 sequence of Spline1DDiff() calls, but it can be several times faster when
1464 called for ordered X[] and X2[].
1465 
1466 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1467  X - spline nodes
1468  Y - function values
1469 
1470 OPTIONAL PARAMETERS:
1471  N - points count:
1472  * N>=2
1473  * if given, only first N points are used
1474  * if not given, automatically detected from X/Y sizes
1475  (len(X) must be equal to len(Y))
1476  BoundLType - boundary condition type for the left boundary
1477  BoundL - left boundary condition (first or second derivative,
1478  depending on the BoundLType)
1479  BoundRType - boundary condition type for the right boundary
1480  BoundR - right boundary condition (first or second derivative,
1481  depending on the BoundRType)
1482 
1483 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
1484  D - derivative values at X[]
1485 
1486 ORDER OF POINTS
1487 
1488 Subroutine automatically sorts points, so caller may pass unsorted array.
1489 Derivative values are correctly reordered on return, so D[I] is always
1490 equal to S'(X[I]) independently of points order.
1491 
1492 SETTING BOUNDARY VALUES:
1493 
1494 The BoundLType/BoundRType parameters can have the following values:
1495  * -1, which corresonds to the periodic (cyclic) boundary conditions.
1496  In this case:
1497  * both BoundLType and BoundRType must be equal to -1.
1498  * BoundL/BoundR are ignored
1499  * Y[last] is ignored (it is assumed to be equal to Y[first]).
1500  * 0, which corresponds to the parabolically terminated spline
1501  (BoundL and/or BoundR are ignored).
1502  * 1, which corresponds to the first derivative boundary condition
1503  * 2, which corresponds to the second derivative boundary condition
1504  * by default, BoundType=0 is used
1505 
1506 PROBLEMS WITH PERIODIC BOUNDARY CONDITIONS:
1507 
1508 Problems with periodic boundary conditions have Y[first_point]=Y[last_point].
1509 However, this subroutine doesn't require you to specify equal values for
1510 the first and last points - it automatically forces them to be equal by
1511 copying Y[first_point] (corresponds to the leftmost, minimal X[]) to
1512 Y[last_point]. However it is recommended to pass consistent values of Y[],
1513 i.e. to make Y[first_point]=Y[last_point].
1514 
1515  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
1516  Copyright 03.09.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
1517 *************************************************************************/
1518 void spline1dgriddiffcubic(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t boundltype, const double boundl, const ae_int_t boundrtype, const double boundr, real_1d_array &d);
1519 void spline1dgriddiffcubic(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, real_1d_array &d);
1520 
1521 
1522 /*************************************************************************
1523 This function solves following problem: given table y[] of function values
1524 at nodes x[], it calculates and returns tables of first and second
1525 function derivatives d1[] and d2[] (calculated at the same nodes x[]).
1526 
1527 This function yields same result as Spline1DBuildCubic() call followed by
1528 sequence of Spline1DDiff() calls, but it can be several times faster when
1529 called for ordered X[] and X2[].
1530 
1531 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1532  X - spline nodes
1533  Y - function values
1534 
1535 OPTIONAL PARAMETERS:
1536  N - points count:
1537  * N>=2
1538  * if given, only first N points are used
1539  * if not given, automatically detected from X/Y sizes
1540  (len(X) must be equal to len(Y))
1541  BoundLType - boundary condition type for the left boundary
1542  BoundL - left boundary condition (first or second derivative,
1543  depending on the BoundLType)
1544  BoundRType - boundary condition type for the right boundary
1545  BoundR - right boundary condition (first or second derivative,
1546  depending on the BoundRType)
1547 
1548 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
1549  D1 - S' values at X[]
1550  D2 - S'' values at X[]
1551 
1552 ORDER OF POINTS
1553 
1554 Subroutine automatically sorts points, so caller may pass unsorted array.
1555 Derivative values are correctly reordered on return, so D[I] is always
1556 equal to S'(X[I]) independently of points order.
1557 
1558 SETTING BOUNDARY VALUES:
1559 
1560 The BoundLType/BoundRType parameters can have the following values:
1561  * -1, which corresonds to the periodic (cyclic) boundary conditions.
1562  In this case:
1563  * both BoundLType and BoundRType must be equal to -1.
1564  * BoundL/BoundR are ignored
1565  * Y[last] is ignored (it is assumed to be equal to Y[first]).
1566  * 0, which corresponds to the parabolically terminated spline
1567  (BoundL and/or BoundR are ignored).
1568  * 1, which corresponds to the first derivative boundary condition
1569  * 2, which corresponds to the second derivative boundary condition
1570  * by default, BoundType=0 is used
1571 
1572 PROBLEMS WITH PERIODIC BOUNDARY CONDITIONS:
1573 
1574 Problems with periodic boundary conditions have Y[first_point]=Y[last_point].
1575 However, this subroutine doesn't require you to specify equal values for
1576 the first and last points - it automatically forces them to be equal by
1577 copying Y[first_point] (corresponds to the leftmost, minimal X[]) to
1578 Y[last_point]. However it is recommended to pass consistent values of Y[],
1579 i.e. to make Y[first_point]=Y[last_point].
1580 
1581  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
1582  Copyright 03.09.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
1583 *************************************************************************/
1584 void spline1dgriddiff2cubic(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t boundltype, const double boundl, const ae_int_t boundrtype, const double boundr, real_1d_array &d1, real_1d_array &d2);
1585 void spline1dgriddiff2cubic(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, real_1d_array &d1, real_1d_array &d2);
1586 
1587 
1588 /*************************************************************************
1589 This function solves following problem: given table y[] of function values
1590 at old nodes x[] and new nodes x2[], it calculates and returns table of
1591 function values y2[] (calculated at x2[]).
1592 
1593 This function yields same result as Spline1DBuildCubic() call followed by
1594 sequence of Spline1DDiff() calls, but it can be several times faster when
1595 called for ordered X[] and X2[].
1596 
1597 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1598  X - old spline nodes
1599  Y - function values
1600  X2 - new spline nodes
1601 
1602 OPTIONAL PARAMETERS:
1603  N - points count:
1604  * N>=2
1605  * if given, only first N points from X/Y are used
1606  * if not given, automatically detected from X/Y sizes
1607  (len(X) must be equal to len(Y))
1608  BoundLType - boundary condition type for the left boundary
1609  BoundL - left boundary condition (first or second derivative,
1610  depending on the BoundLType)
1611  BoundRType - boundary condition type for the right boundary
1612  BoundR - right boundary condition (first or second derivative,
1613  depending on the BoundRType)
1614  N2 - new points count:
1615  * N2>=2
1616  * if given, only first N2 points from X2 are used
1617  * if not given, automatically detected from X2 size
1618 
1619 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
1620  F2 - function values at X2[]
1621 
1622 ORDER OF POINTS
1623 
1624 Subroutine automatically sorts points, so caller may pass unsorted array.
1625 Function values are correctly reordered on return, so F2[I] is always
1626 equal to S(X2[I]) independently of points order.
1627 
1628 SETTING BOUNDARY VALUES:
1629 
1630 The BoundLType/BoundRType parameters can have the following values:
1631  * -1, which corresonds to the periodic (cyclic) boundary conditions.
1632  In this case:
1633  * both BoundLType and BoundRType must be equal to -1.
1634  * BoundL/BoundR are ignored
1635  * Y[last] is ignored (it is assumed to be equal to Y[first]).
1636  * 0, which corresponds to the parabolically terminated spline
1637  (BoundL and/or BoundR are ignored).
1638  * 1, which corresponds to the first derivative boundary condition
1639  * 2, which corresponds to the second derivative boundary condition
1640  * by default, BoundType=0 is used
1641 
1642 PROBLEMS WITH PERIODIC BOUNDARY CONDITIONS:
1643 
1644 Problems with periodic boundary conditions have Y[first_point]=Y[last_point].
1645 However, this subroutine doesn't require you to specify equal values for
1646 the first and last points - it automatically forces them to be equal by
1647 copying Y[first_point] (corresponds to the leftmost, minimal X[]) to
1648 Y[last_point]. However it is recommended to pass consistent values of Y[],
1649 i.e. to make Y[first_point]=Y[last_point].
1650 
1651  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
1652  Copyright 03.09.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
1653 *************************************************************************/
1654 void spline1dconvcubic(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t boundltype, const double boundl, const ae_int_t boundrtype, const double boundr, const real_1d_array &x2, const ae_int_t n2, real_1d_array &y2);
1655 void spline1dconvcubic(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &x2, real_1d_array &y2);
1656 
1657 
1658 /*************************************************************************
1659 This function solves following problem: given table y[] of function values
1660 at old nodes x[] and new nodes x2[], it calculates and returns table of
1661 function values y2[] and derivatives d2[] (calculated at x2[]).
1662 
1663 This function yields same result as Spline1DBuildCubic() call followed by
1664 sequence of Spline1DDiff() calls, but it can be several times faster when
1665 called for ordered X[] and X2[].
1666 
1667 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1668  X - old spline nodes
1669  Y - function values
1670  X2 - new spline nodes
1671 
1672 OPTIONAL PARAMETERS:
1673  N - points count:
1674  * N>=2
1675  * if given, only first N points from X/Y are used
1676  * if not given, automatically detected from X/Y sizes
1677  (len(X) must be equal to len(Y))
1678  BoundLType - boundary condition type for the left boundary
1679  BoundL - left boundary condition (first or second derivative,
1680  depending on the BoundLType)
1681  BoundRType - boundary condition type for the right boundary
1682  BoundR - right boundary condition (first or second derivative,
1683  depending on the BoundRType)
1684  N2 - new points count:
1685  * N2>=2
1686  * if given, only first N2 points from X2 are used
1687  * if not given, automatically detected from X2 size
1688 
1689 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
1690  F2 - function values at X2[]
1691  D2 - first derivatives at X2[]
1692 
1693 ORDER OF POINTS
1694 
1695 Subroutine automatically sorts points, so caller may pass unsorted array.
1696 Function values are correctly reordered on return, so F2[I] is always
1697 equal to S(X2[I]) independently of points order.
1698 
1699 SETTING BOUNDARY VALUES:
1700 
1701 The BoundLType/BoundRType parameters can have the following values:
1702  * -1, which corresonds to the periodic (cyclic) boundary conditions.
1703  In this case:
1704  * both BoundLType and BoundRType must be equal to -1.
1705  * BoundL/BoundR are ignored
1706  * Y[last] is ignored (it is assumed to be equal to Y[first]).
1707  * 0, which corresponds to the parabolically terminated spline
1708  (BoundL and/or BoundR are ignored).
1709  * 1, which corresponds to the first derivative boundary condition
1710  * 2, which corresponds to the second derivative boundary condition
1711  * by default, BoundType=0 is used
1712 
1713 PROBLEMS WITH PERIODIC BOUNDARY CONDITIONS:
1714 
1715 Problems with periodic boundary conditions have Y[first_point]=Y[last_point].
1716 However, this subroutine doesn't require you to specify equal values for
1717 the first and last points - it automatically forces them to be equal by
1718 copying Y[first_point] (corresponds to the leftmost, minimal X[]) to
1719 Y[last_point]. However it is recommended to pass consistent values of Y[],
1720 i.e. to make Y[first_point]=Y[last_point].
1721 
1722  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
1723  Copyright 03.09.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
1724 *************************************************************************/
1725 void spline1dconvdiffcubic(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t boundltype, const double boundl, const ae_int_t boundrtype, const double boundr, const real_1d_array &x2, const ae_int_t n2, real_1d_array &y2, real_1d_array &d2);
1726 void spline1dconvdiffcubic(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &x2, real_1d_array &y2, real_1d_array &d2);
1727 
1728 
1729 /*************************************************************************
1730 This function solves following problem: given table y[] of function values
1731 at old nodes x[] and new nodes x2[], it calculates and returns table of
1732 function values y2[], first and second derivatives d2[] and dd2[]
1733 (calculated at x2[]).
1734 
1735 This function yields same result as Spline1DBuildCubic() call followed by
1736 sequence of Spline1DDiff() calls, but it can be several times faster when
1737 called for ordered X[] and X2[].
1738 
1739 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1740  X - old spline nodes
1741  Y - function values
1742  X2 - new spline nodes
1743 
1744 OPTIONAL PARAMETERS:
1745  N - points count:
1746  * N>=2
1747  * if given, only first N points from X/Y are used
1748  * if not given, automatically detected from X/Y sizes
1749  (len(X) must be equal to len(Y))
1750  BoundLType - boundary condition type for the left boundary
1751  BoundL - left boundary condition (first or second derivative,
1752  depending on the BoundLType)
1753  BoundRType - boundary condition type for the right boundary
1754  BoundR - right boundary condition (first or second derivative,
1755  depending on the BoundRType)
1756  N2 - new points count:
1757  * N2>=2
1758  * if given, only first N2 points from X2 are used
1759  * if not given, automatically detected from X2 size
1760 
1761 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
1762  F2 - function values at X2[]
1763  D2 - first derivatives at X2[]
1764  DD2 - second derivatives at X2[]
1765 
1766 ORDER OF POINTS
1767 
1768 Subroutine automatically sorts points, so caller may pass unsorted array.
1769 Function values are correctly reordered on return, so F2[I] is always
1770 equal to S(X2[I]) independently of points order.
1771 
1772 SETTING BOUNDARY VALUES:
1773 
1774 The BoundLType/BoundRType parameters can have the following values:
1775  * -1, which corresonds to the periodic (cyclic) boundary conditions.
1776  In this case:
1777  * both BoundLType and BoundRType must be equal to -1.
1778  * BoundL/BoundR are ignored
1779  * Y[last] is ignored (it is assumed to be equal to Y[first]).
1780  * 0, which corresponds to the parabolically terminated spline
1781  (BoundL and/or BoundR are ignored).
1782  * 1, which corresponds to the first derivative boundary condition
1783  * 2, which corresponds to the second derivative boundary condition
1784  * by default, BoundType=0 is used
1785 
1786 PROBLEMS WITH PERIODIC BOUNDARY CONDITIONS:
1787 
1788 Problems with periodic boundary conditions have Y[first_point]=Y[last_point].
1789 However, this subroutine doesn't require you to specify equal values for
1790 the first and last points - it automatically forces them to be equal by
1791 copying Y[first_point] (corresponds to the leftmost, minimal X[]) to
1792 Y[last_point]. However it is recommended to pass consistent values of Y[],
1793 i.e. to make Y[first_point]=Y[last_point].
1794 
1795  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
1796  Copyright 03.09.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
1797 *************************************************************************/
1798 void spline1dconvdiff2cubic(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t boundltype, const double boundl, const ae_int_t boundrtype, const double boundr, const real_1d_array &x2, const ae_int_t n2, real_1d_array &y2, real_1d_array &d2, real_1d_array &dd2);
1799 void spline1dconvdiff2cubic(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &x2, real_1d_array &y2, real_1d_array &d2, real_1d_array &dd2);
1800 
1801 
1802 /*************************************************************************
1803 This subroutine builds Catmull-Rom spline interpolant.
1804 
1805 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1806  X - spline nodes, array[0..N-1].
1807  Y - function values, array[0..N-1].
1808 
1809 OPTIONAL PARAMETERS:
1810  N - points count:
1811  * N>=2
1812  * if given, only first N points are used to build spline
1813  * if not given, automatically detected from X/Y sizes
1814  (len(X) must be equal to len(Y))
1815  BoundType - boundary condition type:
1816  * -1 for periodic boundary condition
1817  * 0 for parabolically terminated spline (default)
1818  Tension - tension parameter:
1819  * tension=0 corresponds to classic Catmull-Rom spline (default)
1820  * 0<tension<1 corresponds to more general form - cardinal spline
1821 
1822 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
1823  C - spline interpolant
1824 
1825 
1826 ORDER OF POINTS
1827 
1828 Subroutine automatically sorts points, so caller may pass unsorted array.
1829 
1830 PROBLEMS WITH PERIODIC BOUNDARY CONDITIONS:
1831 
1832 Problems with periodic boundary conditions have Y[first_point]=Y[last_point].
1833 However, this subroutine doesn't require you to specify equal values for
1834 the first and last points - it automatically forces them to be equal by
1835 copying Y[first_point] (corresponds to the leftmost, minimal X[]) to
1836 Y[last_point]. However it is recommended to pass consistent values of Y[],
1837 i.e. to make Y[first_point]=Y[last_point].
1838 
1839  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
1840  Copyright 23.06.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
1841 *************************************************************************/
1842 void spline1dbuildcatmullrom(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t boundtype, const double tension, spline1dinterpolant &c);
1843 void spline1dbuildcatmullrom(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, spline1dinterpolant &c);
1844 
1845 
1846 /*************************************************************************
1847 This subroutine builds Hermite spline interpolant.
1848 
1849 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1850  X - spline nodes, array[0..N-1]
1851  Y - function values, array[0..N-1]
1852  D - derivatives, array[0..N-1]
1853  N - points count (optional):
1854  * N>=2
1855  * if given, only first N points are used to build spline
1856  * if not given, automatically detected from X/Y sizes
1857  (len(X) must be equal to len(Y))
1858 
1859 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
1860  C - spline interpolant.
1861 
1862 
1863 ORDER OF POINTS
1864 
1865 Subroutine automatically sorts points, so caller may pass unsorted array.
1866 
1867  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
1868  Copyright 23.06.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
1869 *************************************************************************/
1870 void spline1dbuildhermite(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &d, const ae_int_t n, spline1dinterpolant &c);
1871 void spline1dbuildhermite(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &d, spline1dinterpolant &c);
1872 
1873 
1874 /*************************************************************************
1875 This subroutine builds Akima spline interpolant
1876 
1877 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1878  X - spline nodes, array[0..N-1]
1879  Y - function values, array[0..N-1]
1880  N - points count (optional):
1881  * N>=2
1882  * if given, only first N points are used to build spline
1883  * if not given, automatically detected from X/Y sizes
1884  (len(X) must be equal to len(Y))
1885 
1886 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
1887  C - spline interpolant
1888 
1889 
1890 ORDER OF POINTS
1891 
1892 Subroutine automatically sorts points, so caller may pass unsorted array.
1893 
1894  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
1895  Copyright 24.06.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
1896 *************************************************************************/
1897 void spline1dbuildakima(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, spline1dinterpolant &c);
1898 void spline1dbuildakima(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, spline1dinterpolant &c);
1899 
1900 
1901 /*************************************************************************
1902 This subroutine calculates the value of the spline at the given point X.
1903 
1904 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1905  C - spline interpolant
1906  X - point
1907 
1908 Result:
1909  S(x)
1910 
1911  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
1912  Copyright 23.06.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
1913 *************************************************************************/
1914 double spline1dcalc(const spline1dinterpolant &c, const double x);
1915 
1916 
1917 /*************************************************************************
1918 This subroutine differentiates the spline.
1919 
1920 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1921  C - spline interpolant.
1922  X - point
1923 
1924 Result:
1925  S - S(x)
1926  DS - S'(x)
1927  D2S - S''(x)
1928 
1929  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
1930  Copyright 24.06.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
1931 *************************************************************************/
1932 void spline1ddiff(const spline1dinterpolant &c, const double x, double &s, double &ds, double &d2s);
1933 
1934 
1935 /*************************************************************************
1936 This subroutine unpacks the spline into the coefficients table.
1937 
1938 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1939  C - spline interpolant.
1940  X - point
1941 
1942 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
1943  Tbl - coefficients table, unpacked format, array[0..N-2, 0..5].
1944  For I = 0...N-2:
1945  Tbl[I,0] = X[i]
1946  Tbl[I,1] = X[i+1]
1947  Tbl[I,2] = C0
1948  Tbl[I,3] = C1
1949  Tbl[I,4] = C2
1950  Tbl[I,5] = C3
1951  On [x[i], x[i+1]] spline is equals to:
1952  S(x) = C0 + C1*t + C2*t^2 + C3*t^3
1953  t = x-x[i]
1954 
1955 NOTE:
1956  You can rebuild spline with Spline1DBuildHermite() function, which
1957  accepts as inputs function values and derivatives at nodes, which are
1958  easy to calculate when you have coefficients.
1959 
1960  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
1961  Copyright 29.06.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
1962 *************************************************************************/
1963 void spline1dunpack(const spline1dinterpolant &c, ae_int_t &n, real_2d_array &tbl);
1964 
1965 
1966 /*************************************************************************
1967 This subroutine performs linear transformation of the spline argument.
1968 
1969 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1970  C - spline interpolant.
1971  A, B- transformation coefficients: x = A*t + B
1972 Result:
1973  C - transformed spline
1974 
1975  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
1976  Copyright 30.06.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
1977 *************************************************************************/
1978 void spline1dlintransx(const spline1dinterpolant &c, const double a, const double b);
1979 
1980 
1981 /*************************************************************************
1982 This subroutine performs linear transformation of the spline.
1983 
1984 INPUT PARAMETERS:
1985  C - spline interpolant.
1986  A, B- transformation coefficients: S2(x) = A*S(x) + B
1987 Result:
1988  C - transformed spline
1989 
1990  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
1991  Copyright 30.06.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
1992 *************************************************************************/
1993 void spline1dlintransy(const spline1dinterpolant &c, const double a, const double b);
1994 
1995 
1996 /*************************************************************************
1997 This subroutine integrates the spline.
1998 
1999 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2000  C - spline interpolant.
2001  X - right bound of the integration interval [a, x],
2002  here 'a' denotes min(x[])
2003 Result:
2004  integral(S(t)dt,a,x)
2005 
2006  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
2007  Copyright 23.06.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
2008 *************************************************************************/
2009 double spline1dintegrate(const spline1dinterpolant &c, const double x);
2010 
2011 
2012 /*************************************************************************
2013 This function builds monotone cubic Hermite interpolant. This interpolant
2014 is monotonic in [x(0),x(n-1)] and is constant outside of this interval.
2015 
2016 In case y[] form non-monotonic sequence, interpolant is piecewise
2017 monotonic. Say, for x=(0,1,2,3,4) and y=(0,1,2,1,0) interpolant will
2018 monotonically grow at [0..2] and monotonically decrease at [2..4].
2019 
2020 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2021  X - spline nodes, array[0..N-1]. Subroutine automatically
2022  sorts points, so caller may pass unsorted array.
2023  Y - function values, array[0..N-1]
2024  N - the number of points(N>=2).
2025 
2026 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2027  C - spline interpolant.
2028 
2029  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
2030  Copyright 21.06.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
2031 *************************************************************************/
2032 void spline1dbuildmonotone(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, spline1dinterpolant &c);
2033 void spline1dbuildmonotone(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, spline1dinterpolant &c);
2034 
2035 /*************************************************************************
2036 Fitting by polynomials in barycentric form. This function provides simple
2037 unterface for unconstrained unweighted fitting. See PolynomialFitWC() if
2038 you need constrained fitting.
2039 
2040 Task is linear, so linear least squares solver is used. Complexity of this
2041 computational scheme is O(N*M^2), mostly dominated by least squares solver
2042 
2043 SEE ALSO:
2044  PolynomialFitWC()
2045 
2046 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2047  X - points, array[0..N-1].
2048  Y - function values, array[0..N-1].
2049  N - number of points, N>0
2050  * if given, only leading N elements of X/Y are used
2051  * if not given, automatically determined from sizes of X/Y
2052  M - number of basis functions (= polynomial_degree + 1), M>=1
2053 
2054 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2055  Info- same format as in LSFitLinearW() subroutine:
2056  * Info>0 task is solved
2057  * Info<=0 an error occurred:
2058  -4 means inconvergence of internal SVD
2059  P - interpolant in barycentric form.
2060  Rep - report, same format as in LSFitLinearW() subroutine.
2061  Following fields are set:
2062  * RMSError rms error on the (X,Y).
2063  * AvgError average error on the (X,Y).
2064  * AvgRelError average relative error on the non-zero Y
2065  * MaxError maximum error
2066  NON-WEIGHTED ERRORS ARE CALCULATED
2067 
2068 NOTES:
2069  you can convert P from barycentric form to the power or Chebyshev
2070  basis with PolynomialBar2Pow() or PolynomialBar2Cheb() functions from
2071  POLINT subpackage.
2072 
2073  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
2074  Copyright 10.12.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
2075 *************************************************************************/
2076 void polynomialfit(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t m, ae_int_t &info, barycentricinterpolant &p, polynomialfitreport &rep);
2077 void polynomialfit(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t m, ae_int_t &info, barycentricinterpolant &p, polynomialfitreport &rep);
2078 
2079 
2080 /*************************************************************************
2081 Weighted fitting by polynomials in barycentric form, with constraints on
2082 function values or first derivatives.
2083 
2084 Small regularizing term is used when solving constrained tasks (to improve
2085 stability).
2086 
2087 Task is linear, so linear least squares solver is used. Complexity of this
2088 computational scheme is O(N*M^2), mostly dominated by least squares solver
2089 
2090 SEE ALSO:
2091  PolynomialFit()
2092 
2093 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2094  X - points, array[0..N-1].
2095  Y - function values, array[0..N-1].
2096  W - weights, array[0..N-1]
2097  Each summand in square sum of approximation deviations from
2098  given values is multiplied by the square of corresponding
2099  weight. Fill it by 1's if you don't want to solve weighted
2100  task.
2101  N - number of points, N>0.
2102  * if given, only leading N elements of X/Y/W are used
2103  * if not given, automatically determined from sizes of X/Y/W
2104  XC - points where polynomial values/derivatives are constrained,
2105  array[0..K-1].
2106  YC - values of constraints, array[0..K-1]
2107  DC - array[0..K-1], types of constraints:
2108  * DC[i]=0 means that P(XC[i])=YC[i]
2109  * DC[i]=1 means that P'(XC[i])=YC[i]
2110  SEE BELOW FOR IMPORTANT INFORMATION ON CONSTRAINTS
2111  K - number of constraints, 0<=K<M.
2112  K=0 means no constraints (XC/YC/DC are not used in such cases)
2113  M - number of basis functions (= polynomial_degree + 1), M>=1
2114 
2115 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2116  Info- same format as in LSFitLinearW() subroutine:
2117  * Info>0 task is solved
2118  * Info<=0 an error occurred:
2119  -4 means inconvergence of internal SVD
2120  -3 means inconsistent constraints
2121  P - interpolant in barycentric form.
2122  Rep - report, same format as in LSFitLinearW() subroutine.
2123  Following fields are set:
2124  * RMSError rms error on the (X,Y).
2125  * AvgError average error on the (X,Y).
2126  * AvgRelError average relative error on the non-zero Y
2127  * MaxError maximum error
2128  NON-WEIGHTED ERRORS ARE CALCULATED
2129 
2130 IMPORTANT:
2131  this subroitine doesn't calculate task's condition number for K<>0.
2132 
2133 NOTES:
2134  you can convert P from barycentric form to the power or Chebyshev
2135  basis with PolynomialBar2Pow() or PolynomialBar2Cheb() functions from
2136  POLINT subpackage.
2137 
2138 SETTING CONSTRAINTS - DANGERS AND OPPORTUNITIES:
2139 
2140 Setting constraints can lead to undesired results, like ill-conditioned
2141 behavior, or inconsistency being detected. From the other side, it allows
2142 us to improve quality of the fit. Here we summarize our experience with
2143 constrained regression splines:
2144 * even simple constraints can be inconsistent, see Wikipedia article on
2145  this subject: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Birkhoff_interpolation
2146 * the greater is M (given fixed constraints), the more chances that
2147  constraints will be consistent
2148 * in the general case, consistency of constraints is NOT GUARANTEED.
2149 * in the one special cases, however, we can guarantee consistency. This
2150  case is: M>1 and constraints on the function values (NOT DERIVATIVES)
2151 
2152 Our final recommendation is to use constraints WHEN AND ONLY when you
2153 can't solve your task without them. Anything beyond special cases given
2154 above is not guaranteed and may result in inconsistency.
2155 
2156  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
2157  Copyright 10.12.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
2158 *************************************************************************/
2159 void polynomialfitwc(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &w, const ae_int_t n, const real_1d_array &xc, const real_1d_array &yc, const integer_1d_array &dc, const ae_int_t k, const ae_int_t m, ae_int_t &info, barycentricinterpolant &p, polynomialfitreport &rep);
2160 void polynomialfitwc(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &w, const real_1d_array &xc, const real_1d_array &yc, const integer_1d_array &dc, const ae_int_t m, ae_int_t &info, barycentricinterpolant &p, polynomialfitreport &rep);
2161 
2162 
2163 /*************************************************************************
2164 Weghted rational least squares fitting using Floater-Hormann rational
2165 functions with optimal D chosen from [0,9], with constraints and
2166 individual weights.
2167 
2168 Equidistant grid with M node on [min(x),max(x)] is used to build basis
2169 functions. Different values of D are tried, optimal D (least WEIGHTED root
2170 mean square error) is chosen. Task is linear, so linear least squares
2171 solver is used. Complexity of this computational scheme is O(N*M^2)
2172 (mostly dominated by the least squares solver).
2173 
2174 SEE ALSO
2175 * BarycentricFitFloaterHormann(), "lightweight" fitting without invididual
2176  weights and constraints.
2177 
2178 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2179  X - points, array[0..N-1].
2180  Y - function values, array[0..N-1].
2181  W - weights, array[0..N-1]
2182  Each summand in square sum of approximation deviations from
2183  given values is multiplied by the square of corresponding
2184  weight. Fill it by 1's if you don't want to solve weighted
2185  task.
2186  N - number of points, N>0.
2187  XC - points where function values/derivatives are constrained,
2188  array[0..K-1].
2189  YC - values of constraints, array[0..K-1]
2190  DC - array[0..K-1], types of constraints:
2191  * DC[i]=0 means that S(XC[i])=YC[i]
2192  * DC[i]=1 means that S'(XC[i])=YC[i]
2193  SEE BELOW FOR IMPORTANT INFORMATION ON CONSTRAINTS
2194  K - number of constraints, 0<=K<M.
2195  K=0 means no constraints (XC/YC/DC are not used in such cases)
2196  M - number of basis functions ( = number_of_nodes), M>=2.
2197 
2198 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2199  Info- same format as in LSFitLinearWC() subroutine.
2200  * Info>0 task is solved
2201  * Info<=0 an error occurred:
2202  -4 means inconvergence of internal SVD
2203  -3 means inconsistent constraints
2204  -1 means another errors in parameters passed
2205  (N<=0, for example)
2206  B - barycentric interpolant.
2207  Rep - report, same format as in LSFitLinearWC() subroutine.
2208  Following fields are set:
2209  * DBest best value of the D parameter
2210  * RMSError rms error on the (X,Y).
2211  * AvgError average error on the (X,Y).
2212  * AvgRelError average relative error on the non-zero Y
2213  * MaxError maximum error
2214  NON-WEIGHTED ERRORS ARE CALCULATED
2215 
2216 IMPORTANT:
2217  this subroutine doesn't calculate task's condition number for K<>0.
2218 
2219 SETTING CONSTRAINTS - DANGERS AND OPPORTUNITIES:
2220 
2221 Setting constraints can lead to undesired results, like ill-conditioned
2222 behavior, or inconsistency being detected. From the other side, it allows
2223 us to improve quality of the fit. Here we summarize our experience with
2224 constrained barycentric interpolants:
2225 * excessive constraints can be inconsistent. Floater-Hormann basis
2226  functions aren't as flexible as splines (although they are very smooth).
2227 * the more evenly constraints are spread across [min(x),max(x)], the more
2228  chances that they will be consistent
2229 * the greater is M (given fixed constraints), the more chances that
2230  constraints will be consistent
2231 * in the general case, consistency of constraints IS NOT GUARANTEED.
2232 * in the several special cases, however, we CAN guarantee consistency.
2233 * one of this cases is constraints on the function VALUES at the interval
2234  boundaries. Note that consustency of the constraints on the function
2235  DERIVATIVES is NOT guaranteed (you can use in such cases cubic splines
2236  which are more flexible).
2237 * another special case is ONE constraint on the function value (OR, but
2238  not AND, derivative) anywhere in the interval
2239 
2240 Our final recommendation is to use constraints WHEN AND ONLY WHEN you
2241 can't solve your task without them. Anything beyond special cases given
2242 above is not guaranteed and may result in inconsistency.
2243 
2244  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
2245  Copyright 18.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
2246 *************************************************************************/
2247 void barycentricfitfloaterhormannwc(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &w, const ae_int_t n, const real_1d_array &xc, const real_1d_array &yc, const integer_1d_array &dc, const ae_int_t k, const ae_int_t m, ae_int_t &info, barycentricinterpolant &b, barycentricfitreport &rep);
2248 
2249 
2250 /*************************************************************************
2251 Rational least squares fitting using Floater-Hormann rational functions
2252 with optimal D chosen from [0,9].
2253 
2254 Equidistant grid with M node on [min(x),max(x)] is used to build basis
2255 functions. Different values of D are tried, optimal D (least root mean
2256 square error) is chosen. Task is linear, so linear least squares solver
2257 is used. Complexity of this computational scheme is O(N*M^2) (mostly
2258 dominated by the least squares solver).
2259 
2260 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2261  X - points, array[0..N-1].
2262  Y - function values, array[0..N-1].
2263  N - number of points, N>0.
2264  M - number of basis functions ( = number_of_nodes), M>=2.
2265 
2266 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2267  Info- same format as in LSFitLinearWC() subroutine.
2268  * Info>0 task is solved
