2269  * Info<=0 an error occurred:
2270  -4 means inconvergence of internal SVD
2271  -3 means inconsistent constraints
2272  B - barycentric interpolant.
2273  Rep - report, same format as in LSFitLinearWC() subroutine.
2274  Following fields are set:
2275  * DBest best value of the D parameter
2276  * RMSError rms error on the (X,Y).
2277  * AvgError average error on the (X,Y).
2278  * AvgRelError average relative error on the non-zero Y
2279  * MaxError maximum error
2280  NON-WEIGHTED ERRORS ARE CALCULATED
2281 
2282  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
2283  Copyright 18.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
2284 *************************************************************************/
2285 void barycentricfitfloaterhormann(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t m, ae_int_t &info, barycentricinterpolant &b, barycentricfitreport &rep);
2286 
2287 
2288 /*************************************************************************
2289 Rational least squares fitting using Floater-Hormann rational functions
2290 with optimal D chosen from [0,9].
2291 
2292 Equidistant grid with M node on [min(x),max(x)] is used to build basis
2293 functions. Different values of D are tried, optimal D (least root mean
2294 square error) is chosen. Task is linear, so linear least squares solver
2295 is used. Complexity of this computational scheme is O(N*M^2) (mostly
2296 dominated by the least squares solver).
2297 
2298 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2299  X - points, array[0..N-1].
2300  Y - function values, array[0..N-1].
2301  N - number of points, N>0.
2302  M - number of basis functions ( = number_of_nodes), M>=2.
2303 
2304 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2305  Info- same format as in LSFitLinearWC() subroutine.
2306  * Info>0 task is solved
2307  * Info<=0 an error occurred:
2308  -4 means inconvergence of internal SVD
2309  -3 means inconsistent constraints
2310  B - barycentric interpolant.
2311  Rep - report, same format as in LSFitLinearWC() subroutine.
2312  Following fields are set:
2313  * DBest best value of the D parameter
2314  * RMSError rms error on the (X,Y).
2315  * AvgError average error on the (X,Y).
2316  * AvgRelError average relative error on the non-zero Y
2317  * MaxError maximum error
2318  NON-WEIGHTED ERRORS ARE CALCULATED
2319 
2320  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
2321  Copyright 18.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
2322 *************************************************************************/
2323 void spline1dfitpenalized(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t m, const double rho, ae_int_t &info, spline1dinterpolant &s, spline1dfitreport &rep);
2324 void spline1dfitpenalized(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t m, const double rho, ae_int_t &info, spline1dinterpolant &s, spline1dfitreport &rep);
2325 
2326 
2327 /*************************************************************************
2328 Weighted fitting by penalized cubic spline.
2329 
2330 Equidistant grid with M nodes on [min(x,xc),max(x,xc)] is used to build
2331 basis functions. Basis functions are cubic splines with natural boundary
2332 conditions. Problem is regularized by adding non-linearity penalty to the
2333 usual least squares penalty function:
2334 
2335  S(x) = arg min { LS + P }, where
2336  LS = SUM { w[i]^2*(y[i] - S(x[i]))^2 } - least squares penalty
2337  P = C*10^rho*integral{ S''(x)^2*dx } - non-linearity penalty
2338  rho - tunable constant given by user
2339  C - automatically determined scale parameter,
2340  makes penalty invariant with respect to scaling of X, Y, W.
2341 
2342 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2343  X - points, array[0..N-1].
2344  Y - function values, array[0..N-1].
2345  W - weights, array[0..N-1]
2346  Each summand in square sum of approximation deviations from
2347  given values is multiplied by the square of corresponding
2348  weight. Fill it by 1's if you don't want to solve weighted
2349  problem.
2350  N - number of points (optional):
2351  * N>0
2352  * if given, only first N elements of X/Y/W are processed
2353  * if not given, automatically determined from X/Y/W sizes
2354  M - number of basis functions ( = number_of_nodes), M>=4.
2355  Rho - regularization constant passed by user. It penalizes
2356  nonlinearity in the regression spline. It is logarithmically
2357  scaled, i.e. actual value of regularization constant is
2358  calculated as 10^Rho. It is automatically scaled so that:
2359  * Rho=2.0 corresponds to moderate amount of nonlinearity
2360  * generally, it should be somewhere in the [-8.0,+8.0]
2361  If you do not want to penalize nonlineary,
2362  pass small Rho. Values as low as -15 should work.
2363 
2364 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2365  Info- same format as in LSFitLinearWC() subroutine.
2366  * Info>0 task is solved
2367  * Info<=0 an error occurred:
2368  -4 means inconvergence of internal SVD or
2369  Cholesky decomposition; problem may be
2370  too ill-conditioned (very rare)
2371  S - spline interpolant.
2372  Rep - Following fields are set:
2373  * RMSError rms error on the (X,Y).
2374  * AvgError average error on the (X,Y).
2375  * AvgRelError average relative error on the non-zero Y
2376  * MaxError maximum error
2377  NON-WEIGHTED ERRORS ARE CALCULATED
2378 
2379 IMPORTANT:
2380  this subroitine doesn't calculate task's condition number for K<>0.
2381 
2382 NOTE 1: additional nodes are added to the spline outside of the fitting
2383 interval to force linearity when x<min(x,xc) or x>max(x,xc). It is done
2384 for consistency - we penalize non-linearity at [min(x,xc),max(x,xc)], so
2385 it is natural to force linearity outside of this interval.
2386 
2387 NOTE 2: function automatically sorts points, so caller may pass unsorted
2388 array.
2389 
2390  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
2391  Copyright 19.10.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
2392 *************************************************************************/
2393 void spline1dfitpenalizedw(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &w, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t m, const double rho, ae_int_t &info, spline1dinterpolant &s, spline1dfitreport &rep);
2394 void spline1dfitpenalizedw(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &w, const ae_int_t m, const double rho, ae_int_t &info, spline1dinterpolant &s, spline1dfitreport &rep);
2395 
2396 
2397 /*************************************************************************
2398 Weighted fitting by cubic spline, with constraints on function values or
2399 derivatives.
2400 
2401 Equidistant grid with M-2 nodes on [min(x,xc),max(x,xc)] is used to build
2402 basis functions. Basis functions are cubic splines with continuous second
2403 derivatives and non-fixed first derivatives at interval ends. Small
2404 regularizing term is used when solving constrained tasks (to improve
2405 stability).
2406 
2407 Task is linear, so linear least squares solver is used. Complexity of this
2408 computational scheme is O(N*M^2), mostly dominated by least squares solver
2409 
2410 SEE ALSO
2411  Spline1DFitHermiteWC() - fitting by Hermite splines (more flexible,
2412  less smooth)
2413  Spline1DFitCubic() - "lightweight" fitting by cubic splines,
2414  without invididual weights and constraints
2415 
2416 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2417  X - points, array[0..N-1].
2418  Y - function values, array[0..N-1].
2419  W - weights, array[0..N-1]
2420  Each summand in square sum of approximation deviations from
2421  given values is multiplied by the square of corresponding
2422  weight. Fill it by 1's if you don't want to solve weighted
2423  task.
2424  N - number of points (optional):
2425  * N>0
2426  * if given, only first N elements of X/Y/W are processed
2427  * if not given, automatically determined from X/Y/W sizes
2428  XC - points where spline values/derivatives are constrained,
2429  array[0..K-1].
2430  YC - values of constraints, array[0..K-1]
2431  DC - array[0..K-1], types of constraints:
2432  * DC[i]=0 means that S(XC[i])=YC[i]
2433  * DC[i]=1 means that S'(XC[i])=YC[i]
2434  SEE BELOW FOR IMPORTANT INFORMATION ON CONSTRAINTS
2435  K - number of constraints (optional):
2436  * 0<=K<M.
2437  * K=0 means no constraints (XC/YC/DC are not used)
2438  * if given, only first K elements of XC/YC/DC are used
2439  * if not given, automatically determined from XC/YC/DC
2440  M - number of basis functions ( = number_of_nodes+2), M>=4.
2441 
2442 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2443  Info- same format as in LSFitLinearWC() subroutine.
2444  * Info>0 task is solved
2445  * Info<=0 an error occurred:
2446  -4 means inconvergence of internal SVD
2447  -3 means inconsistent constraints
2448  S - spline interpolant.
2449  Rep - report, same format as in LSFitLinearWC() subroutine.
2450  Following fields are set:
2451  * RMSError rms error on the (X,Y).
2452  * AvgError average error on the (X,Y).
2453  * AvgRelError average relative error on the non-zero Y
2454  * MaxError maximum error
2455  NON-WEIGHTED ERRORS ARE CALCULATED
2456 
2457 IMPORTANT:
2458  this subroitine doesn't calculate task's condition number for K<>0.
2459 
2460 
2461 ORDER OF POINTS
2462 
2463 Subroutine automatically sorts points, so caller may pass unsorted array.
2464 
2465 SETTING CONSTRAINTS - DANGERS AND OPPORTUNITIES:
2466 
2467 Setting constraints can lead to undesired results, like ill-conditioned
2468 behavior, or inconsistency being detected. From the other side, it allows
2469 us to improve quality of the fit. Here we summarize our experience with
2470 constrained regression splines:
2471 * excessive constraints can be inconsistent. Splines are piecewise cubic
2472  functions, and it is easy to create an example, where large number of
2473  constraints concentrated in small area will result in inconsistency.
2474  Just because spline is not flexible enough to satisfy all of them. And
2475  same constraints spread across the [min(x),max(x)] will be perfectly
2476  consistent.
2477 * the more evenly constraints are spread across [min(x),max(x)], the more
2478  chances that they will be consistent
2479 * the greater is M (given fixed constraints), the more chances that
2480  constraints will be consistent
2481 * in the general case, consistency of constraints IS NOT GUARANTEED.
2482 * in the several special cases, however, we CAN guarantee consistency.
2483 * one of this cases is constraints on the function values AND/OR its
2484  derivatives at the interval boundaries.
2485 * another special case is ONE constraint on the function value (OR, but
2486  not AND, derivative) anywhere in the interval
2487 
2488 Our final recommendation is to use constraints WHEN AND ONLY WHEN you
2489 can't solve your task without them. Anything beyond special cases given
2490 above is not guaranteed and may result in inconsistency.
2491 
2492 
2493  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
2494  Copyright 18.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
2495 *************************************************************************/
2496 void spline1dfitcubicwc(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &w, const ae_int_t n, const real_1d_array &xc, const real_1d_array &yc, const integer_1d_array &dc, const ae_int_t k, const ae_int_t m, ae_int_t &info, spline1dinterpolant &s, spline1dfitreport &rep);
2497 void spline1dfitcubicwc(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &w, const real_1d_array &xc, const real_1d_array &yc, const integer_1d_array &dc, const ae_int_t m, ae_int_t &info, spline1dinterpolant &s, spline1dfitreport &rep);
2498 
2499 
2500 /*************************************************************************
2501 Weighted fitting by Hermite spline, with constraints on function values
2502 or first derivatives.
2503 
2504 Equidistant grid with M nodes on [min(x,xc),max(x,xc)] is used to build
2505 basis functions. Basis functions are Hermite splines. Small regularizing
2506 term is used when solving constrained tasks (to improve stability).
2507 
2508 Task is linear, so linear least squares solver is used. Complexity of this
2509 computational scheme is O(N*M^2), mostly dominated by least squares solver
2510 
2511 SEE ALSO
2512  Spline1DFitCubicWC() - fitting by Cubic splines (less flexible,
2513  more smooth)
2514  Spline1DFitHermite() - "lightweight" Hermite fitting, without
2515  invididual weights and constraints
2516 
2517 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2518  X - points, array[0..N-1].
2519  Y - function values, array[0..N-1].
2520  W - weights, array[0..N-1]
2521  Each summand in square sum of approximation deviations from
2522  given values is multiplied by the square of corresponding
2523  weight. Fill it by 1's if you don't want to solve weighted
2524  task.
2525  N - number of points (optional):
2526  * N>0
2527  * if given, only first N elements of X/Y/W are processed
2528  * if not given, automatically determined from X/Y/W sizes
2529  XC - points where spline values/derivatives are constrained,
2530  array[0..K-1].
2531  YC - values of constraints, array[0..K-1]
2532  DC - array[0..K-1], types of constraints:
2533  * DC[i]=0 means that S(XC[i])=YC[i]
2534  * DC[i]=1 means that S'(XC[i])=YC[i]
2535  SEE BELOW FOR IMPORTANT INFORMATION ON CONSTRAINTS
2536  K - number of constraints (optional):
2537  * 0<=K<M.
2538  * K=0 means no constraints (XC/YC/DC are not used)
2539  * if given, only first K elements of XC/YC/DC are used
2540  * if not given, automatically determined from XC/YC/DC
2541  M - number of basis functions (= 2 * number of nodes),
2542  M>=4,
2543  M IS EVEN!
2544 
2545 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2546  Info- same format as in LSFitLinearW() subroutine:
2547  * Info>0 task is solved
2548  * Info<=0 an error occurred:
2549  -4 means inconvergence of internal SVD
2550  -3 means inconsistent constraints
2551  -2 means odd M was passed (which is not supported)
2552  -1 means another errors in parameters passed
2553  (N<=0, for example)
2554  S - spline interpolant.
2555  Rep - report, same format as in LSFitLinearW() subroutine.
2556  Following fields are set:
2557  * RMSError rms error on the (X,Y).
2558  * AvgError average error on the (X,Y).
2559  * AvgRelError average relative error on the non-zero Y
2560  * MaxError maximum error
2561  NON-WEIGHTED ERRORS ARE CALCULATED
2562 
2563 IMPORTANT:
2564  this subroitine doesn't calculate task's condition number for K<>0.
2565 
2566 IMPORTANT:
2567  this subroitine supports only even M's
2568 
2569 
2570 ORDER OF POINTS
2571 
2572 Subroutine automatically sorts points, so caller may pass unsorted array.
2573 
2574 SETTING CONSTRAINTS - DANGERS AND OPPORTUNITIES:
2575 
2576 Setting constraints can lead to undesired results, like ill-conditioned
2577 behavior, or inconsistency being detected. From the other side, it allows
2578 us to improve quality of the fit. Here we summarize our experience with
2579 constrained regression splines:
2580 * excessive constraints can be inconsistent. Splines are piecewise cubic
2581  functions, and it is easy to create an example, where large number of
2582  constraints concentrated in small area will result in inconsistency.
2583  Just because spline is not flexible enough to satisfy all of them. And
2584  same constraints spread across the [min(x),max(x)] will be perfectly
2585  consistent.
2586 * the more evenly constraints are spread across [min(x),max(x)], the more
2587  chances that they will be consistent
2588 * the greater is M (given fixed constraints), the more chances that
2589  constraints will be consistent
2590 * in the general case, consistency of constraints is NOT GUARANTEED.
2591 * in the several special cases, however, we can guarantee consistency.
2592 * one of this cases is M>=4 and constraints on the function value
2593  (AND/OR its derivative) at the interval boundaries.
2594 * another special case is M>=4 and ONE constraint on the function value
2595  (OR, BUT NOT AND, derivative) anywhere in [min(x),max(x)]
2596 
2597 Our final recommendation is to use constraints WHEN AND ONLY when you
2598 can't solve your task without them. Anything beyond special cases given
2599 above is not guaranteed and may result in inconsistency.
2600 
2601  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
2602  Copyright 18.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
2603 *************************************************************************/
2604 void spline1dfithermitewc(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &w, const ae_int_t n, const real_1d_array &xc, const real_1d_array &yc, const integer_1d_array &dc, const ae_int_t k, const ae_int_t m, ae_int_t &info, spline1dinterpolant &s, spline1dfitreport &rep);
2605 void spline1dfithermitewc(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &w, const real_1d_array &xc, const real_1d_array &yc, const integer_1d_array &dc, const ae_int_t m, ae_int_t &info, spline1dinterpolant &s, spline1dfitreport &rep);
2606 
2607 
2608 /*************************************************************************
2609 Least squares fitting by cubic spline.
2610 
2611 This subroutine is "lightweight" alternative for more complex and feature-
2612 rich Spline1DFitCubicWC(). See Spline1DFitCubicWC() for more information
2613 about subroutine parameters (we don't duplicate it here because of length)
2614 
2615  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
2616  Copyright 18.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
2617 *************************************************************************/
2618 void spline1dfitcubic(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t m, ae_int_t &info, spline1dinterpolant &s, spline1dfitreport &rep);
2619 void spline1dfitcubic(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t m, ae_int_t &info, spline1dinterpolant &s, spline1dfitreport &rep);
2620 
2621 
2622 /*************************************************************************
2623 Least squares fitting by Hermite spline.
2624 
2625 This subroutine is "lightweight" alternative for more complex and feature-
2626 rich Spline1DFitHermiteWC(). See Spline1DFitHermiteWC() description for
2627 more information about subroutine parameters (we don't duplicate it here
2628 because of length).
2629 
2630  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
2631  Copyright 18.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
2632 *************************************************************************/
2633 void spline1dfithermite(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t m, ae_int_t &info, spline1dinterpolant &s, spline1dfitreport &rep);
2634 void spline1dfithermite(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t m, ae_int_t &info, spline1dinterpolant &s, spline1dfitreport &rep);
2635 
2636 
2637 /*************************************************************************
2638 Weighted linear least squares fitting.
2639 
2640 QR decomposition is used to reduce task to MxM, then triangular solver or
2641 SVD-based solver is used depending on condition number of the system. It
2642 allows to maximize speed and retain decent accuracy.
2643 
2644 IMPORTANT: if you want to perform polynomial fitting, it may be more
2645  convenient to use PolynomialFit() function. This function gives
2646  best results on polynomial problems and solves numerical
2647  stability issues which arise when you fit high-degree
2648  polynomials to your data.
2649 
2650 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2651  Y - array[0..N-1] Function values in N points.
2652  W - array[0..N-1] Weights corresponding to function values.
2653  Each summand in square sum of approximation deviations
2654  from given values is multiplied by the square of
2655  corresponding weight.
2656  FMatrix - a table of basis functions values, array[0..N-1, 0..M-1].
2657  FMatrix[I, J] - value of J-th basis function in I-th point.
2658  N - number of points used. N>=1.
2659  M - number of basis functions, M>=1.
2660 
2661 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2662  Info - error code:
2663  * -4 internal SVD decomposition subroutine failed (very
2664  rare and for degenerate systems only)
2665  * -1 incorrect N/M were specified
2666  * 1 task is solved
2667  C - decomposition coefficients, array[0..M-1]
2668  Rep - fitting report. Following fields are set:
2669  * Rep.TaskRCond reciprocal of condition number
2670  * R2 non-adjusted coefficient of determination
2671  (non-weighted)
2672  * RMSError rms error on the (X,Y).
2673  * AvgError average error on the (X,Y).
2674  * AvgRelError average relative error on the non-zero Y
2675  * MaxError maximum error
2676  NON-WEIGHTED ERRORS ARE CALCULATED
2677 
2678 ERRORS IN PARAMETERS
2679 
2680 This solver also calculates different kinds of errors in parameters and
2681 fills corresponding fields of report:
2682 * Rep.CovPar covariance matrix for parameters, array[K,K].
2683 * Rep.ErrPar errors in parameters, array[K],
2684  errpar = sqrt(diag(CovPar))
2685 * Rep.ErrCurve vector of fit errors - standard deviations of empirical
2686  best-fit curve from "ideal" best-fit curve built with
2687  infinite number of samples, array[N].
2688  errcurve = sqrt(diag(F*CovPar*F')),
2689  where F is functions matrix.
2690 * Rep.Noise vector of per-point estimates of noise, array[N]
2691 
2692 NOTE: noise in the data is estimated as follows:
2693  * for fitting without user-supplied weights all points are
2694  assumed to have same level of noise, which is estimated from
2695  the data
2696  * for fitting with user-supplied weights we assume that noise
2697  level in I-th point is inversely proportional to Ith weight.
2698  Coefficient of proportionality is estimated from the data.
2699 
2700 NOTE: we apply small amount of regularization when we invert squared
2701  Jacobian and calculate covariance matrix. It guarantees that
2702  algorithm won't divide by zero during inversion, but skews
2703  error estimates a bit (fractional error is about 10^-9).
2704 
2705  However, we believe that this difference is insignificant for
2706  all practical purposes except for the situation when you want
2707  to compare ALGLIB results with "reference" implementation up
2708  to the last significant digit.
2709 
2710 NOTE: covariance matrix is estimated using correction for degrees
2711  of freedom (covariances are divided by N-M instead of dividing
2712  by N).
2713 
2714  -- ALGLIB --
2715  Copyright 17.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
2716 *************************************************************************/
2717 void lsfitlinearw(const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &w, const real_2d_array &fmatrix, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t m, ae_int_t &info, real_1d_array &c, lsfitreport &rep);
2718 void lsfitlinearw(const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &w, const real_2d_array &fmatrix, ae_int_t &info, real_1d_array &c, lsfitreport &rep);
2719 
2720 
2721 /*************************************************************************
2722 Weighted constained linear least squares fitting.
2723 
2724 This is variation of LSFitLinearW(), which searchs for min|A*x=b| given
2725 that K additional constraints C*x=bc are satisfied. It reduces original
2726 task to modified one: min|B*y-d| WITHOUT constraints, then LSFitLinearW()
2727 is called.
2728 
2729 IMPORTANT: if you want to perform polynomial fitting, it may be more
2730  convenient to use PolynomialFit() function. This function gives
2731  best results on polynomial problems and solves numerical
2732  stability issues which arise when you fit high-degree
2733  polynomials to your data.
2734 
2735 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2736  Y - array[0..N-1] Function values in N points.
2737  W - array[0..N-1] Weights corresponding to function values.
2738  Each summand in square sum of approximation deviations
2739  from given values is multiplied by the square of
2740  corresponding weight.
2741  FMatrix - a table of basis functions values, array[0..N-1, 0..M-1].
2742  FMatrix[I,J] - value of J-th basis function in I-th point.
2743  CMatrix - a table of constraints, array[0..K-1,0..M].
2744  I-th row of CMatrix corresponds to I-th linear constraint:
2745  CMatrix[I,0]*C[0] + ... + CMatrix[I,M-1]*C[M-1] = CMatrix[I,M]
2746  N - number of points used. N>=1.
2747  M - number of basis functions, M>=1.
2748  K - number of constraints, 0 <= K < M
2749  K=0 corresponds to absence of constraints.
2750 
2751 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2752  Info - error code:
2753  * -4 internal SVD decomposition subroutine failed (very
2754  rare and for degenerate systems only)
2755  * -3 either too many constraints (M or more),
2756  degenerate constraints (some constraints are
2757  repetead twice) or inconsistent constraints were
2758  specified.
2759  * 1 task is solved
2760  C - decomposition coefficients, array[0..M-1]
2761  Rep - fitting report. Following fields are set:
2762  * R2 non-adjusted coefficient of determination
2763  (non-weighted)
2764  * RMSError rms error on the (X,Y).
2765  * AvgError average error on the (X,Y).
2766  * AvgRelError average relative error on the non-zero Y
2767  * MaxError maximum error
2768  NON-WEIGHTED ERRORS ARE CALCULATED
2769 
2770 IMPORTANT:
2771  this subroitine doesn't calculate task's condition number for K<>0.
2772 
2773 ERRORS IN PARAMETERS
2774 
2775 This solver also calculates different kinds of errors in parameters and
2776 fills corresponding fields of report:
2777 * Rep.CovPar covariance matrix for parameters, array[K,K].
2778 * Rep.ErrPar errors in parameters, array[K],
2779  errpar = sqrt(diag(CovPar))
2780 * Rep.ErrCurve vector of fit errors - standard deviations of empirical
2781  best-fit curve from "ideal" best-fit curve built with
2782  infinite number of samples, array[N].
2783  errcurve = sqrt(diag(F*CovPar*F')),
2784  where F is functions matrix.
2785 * Rep.Noise vector of per-point estimates of noise, array[N]
2786 
2787 IMPORTANT: errors in parameters are calculated without taking into
2788  account boundary/linear constraints! Presence of constraints
2789  changes distribution of errors, but there is no easy way to
2790  account for constraints when you calculate covariance matrix.
2791 
2792 NOTE: noise in the data is estimated as follows:
2793  * for fitting without user-supplied weights all points are
2794  assumed to have same level of noise, which is estimated from
2795  the data
2796  * for fitting with user-supplied weights we assume that noise
2797  level in I-th point is inversely proportional to Ith weight.
2798  Coefficient of proportionality is estimated from the data.
2799 
2800 NOTE: we apply small amount of regularization when we invert squared
2801  Jacobian and calculate covariance matrix. It guarantees that
2802  algorithm won't divide by zero during inversion, but skews
2803  error estimates a bit (fractional error is about 10^-9).
2804 
2805  However, we believe that this difference is insignificant for
2806  all practical purposes except for the situation when you want
2807  to compare ALGLIB results with "reference" implementation up
2808  to the last significant digit.
2809 
2810 NOTE: covariance matrix is estimated using correction for degrees
2811  of freedom (covariances are divided by N-M instead of dividing
2812  by N).
2813 
2814  -- ALGLIB --
2815  Copyright 07.09.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
2816 *************************************************************************/
2817 void lsfitlinearwc(const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &w, const real_2d_array &fmatrix, const real_2d_array &cmatrix, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t m, const ae_int_t k, ae_int_t &info, real_1d_array &c, lsfitreport &rep);
2818 void lsfitlinearwc(const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &w, const real_2d_array &fmatrix, const real_2d_array &cmatrix, ae_int_t &info, real_1d_array &c, lsfitreport &rep);
2819 
2820 
2821 /*************************************************************************
2822 Linear least squares fitting.
2823 
2824 QR decomposition is used to reduce task to MxM, then triangular solver or
2825 SVD-based solver is used depending on condition number of the system. It
2826 allows to maximize speed and retain decent accuracy.
2827 
2828 IMPORTANT: if you want to perform polynomial fitting, it may be more
2829  convenient to use PolynomialFit() function. This function gives
2830  best results on polynomial problems and solves numerical
2831  stability issues which arise when you fit high-degree
2832  polynomials to your data.
2833 
2834 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2835  Y - array[0..N-1] Function values in N points.
2836  FMatrix - a table of basis functions values, array[0..N-1, 0..M-1].
2837  FMatrix[I, J] - value of J-th basis function in I-th point.
2838  N - number of points used. N>=1.
2839  M - number of basis functions, M>=1.
2840 
2841 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2842  Info - error code:
2843  * -4 internal SVD decomposition subroutine failed (very
2844  rare and for degenerate systems only)
2845  * 1 task is solved
2846  C - decomposition coefficients, array[0..M-1]
2847  Rep - fitting report. Following fields are set:
2848  * Rep.TaskRCond reciprocal of condition number
2849  * R2 non-adjusted coefficient of determination
2850  (non-weighted)
2851  * RMSError rms error on the (X,Y).
2852  * AvgError average error on the (X,Y).
2853  * AvgRelError average relative error on the non-zero Y
2854  * MaxError maximum error
2855  NON-WEIGHTED ERRORS ARE CALCULATED
2856 
2857 ERRORS IN PARAMETERS
2858 
2859 This solver also calculates different kinds of errors in parameters and
2860 fills corresponding fields of report:
2861 * Rep.CovPar covariance matrix for parameters, array[K,K].
2862 * Rep.ErrPar errors in parameters, array[K],
2863  errpar = sqrt(diag(CovPar))
2864 * Rep.ErrCurve vector of fit errors - standard deviations of empirical
2865  best-fit curve from "ideal" best-fit curve built with
2866  infinite number of samples, array[N].
2867  errcurve = sqrt(diag(F*CovPar*F')),
2868  where F is functions matrix.
2869 * Rep.Noise vector of per-point estimates of noise, array[N]
2870 
2871 NOTE: noise in the data is estimated as follows:
2872  * for fitting without user-supplied weights all points are
2873  assumed to have same level of noise, which is estimated from
2874  the data
2875  * for fitting with user-supplied weights we assume that noise
2876  level in I-th point is inversely proportional to Ith weight.
2877  Coefficient of proportionality is estimated from the data.
2878 
2879 NOTE: we apply small amount of regularization when we invert squared
2880  Jacobian and calculate covariance matrix. It guarantees that
2881  algorithm won't divide by zero during inversion, but skews
2882  error estimates a bit (fractional error is about 10^-9).
2883 
2884  However, we believe that this difference is insignificant for
2885  all practical purposes except for the situation when you want
2886  to compare ALGLIB results with "reference" implementation up
2887  to the last significant digit.
2888 
2889 NOTE: covariance matrix is estimated using correction for degrees
2890  of freedom (covariances are divided by N-M instead of dividing
2891  by N).
2892 
2893  -- ALGLIB --
2894  Copyright 17.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
2895 *************************************************************************/
2896 void lsfitlinear(const real_1d_array &y, const real_2d_array &fmatrix, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t m, ae_int_t &info, real_1d_array &c, lsfitreport &rep);
2897 void lsfitlinear(const real_1d_array &y, const real_2d_array &fmatrix, ae_int_t &info, real_1d_array &c, lsfitreport &rep);
2898 
2899 
2900 /*************************************************************************
2901 Constained linear least squares fitting.
2902 
2903 This is variation of LSFitLinear(), which searchs for min|A*x=b| given
2904 that K additional constraints C*x=bc are satisfied. It reduces original
2905 task to modified one: min|B*y-d| WITHOUT constraints, then LSFitLinear()
2906 is called.
2907 
2908 IMPORTANT: if you want to perform polynomial fitting, it may be more
2909  convenient to use PolynomialFit() function. This function gives
2910  best results on polynomial problems and solves numerical
2911  stability issues which arise when you fit high-degree
2912  polynomials to your data.
2913 
2914 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2915  Y - array[0..N-1] Function values in N points.
2916  FMatrix - a table of basis functions values, array[0..N-1, 0..M-1].
2917  FMatrix[I,J] - value of J-th basis function in I-th point.
2918  CMatrix - a table of constraints, array[0..K-1,0..M].
2919  I-th row of CMatrix corresponds to I-th linear constraint:
2920  CMatrix[I,0]*C[0] + ... + CMatrix[I,M-1]*C[M-1] = CMatrix[I,M]
2921  N - number of points used. N>=1.
2922  M - number of basis functions, M>=1.
2923  K - number of constraints, 0 <= K < M
2924  K=0 corresponds to absence of constraints.
2925 
2926 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2927  Info - error code:
2928  * -4 internal SVD decomposition subroutine failed (very
2929  rare and for degenerate systems only)
2930  * -3 either too many constraints (M or more),
2931  degenerate constraints (some constraints are
2932  repetead twice) or inconsistent constraints were
2933  specified.
2934  * 1 task is solved
2935  C - decomposition coefficients, array[0..M-1]
2936  Rep - fitting report. Following fields are set:
2937  * R2 non-adjusted coefficient of determination
2938  (non-weighted)
2939  * RMSError rms error on the (X,Y).
2940  * AvgError average error on the (X,Y).
2941  * AvgRelError average relative error on the non-zero Y
2942  * MaxError maximum error
2943  NON-WEIGHTED ERRORS ARE CALCULATED
2944 
2945 IMPORTANT:
2946  this subroitine doesn't calculate task's condition number for K<>0.
2947 
2948 ERRORS IN PARAMETERS
2949 
2950 This solver also calculates different kinds of errors in parameters and
2951 fills corresponding fields of report:
2952 * Rep.CovPar covariance matrix for parameters, array[K,K].
2953 * Rep.ErrPar errors in parameters, array[K],
2954  errpar = sqrt(diag(CovPar))
2955 * Rep.ErrCurve vector of fit errors - standard deviations of empirical
2956  best-fit curve from "ideal" best-fit curve built with
2957  infinite number of samples, array[N].
2958  errcurve = sqrt(diag(F*CovPar*F')),
2959  where F is functions matrix.
2960 * Rep.Noise vector of per-point estimates of noise, array[N]
2961 
2962 IMPORTANT: errors in parameters are calculated without taking into
2963  account boundary/linear constraints! Presence of constraints
2964  changes distribution of errors, but there is no easy way to
2965  account for constraints when you calculate covariance matrix.
2966 
2967 NOTE: noise in the data is estimated as follows:
2968  * for fitting without user-supplied weights all points are
2969  assumed to have same level of noise, which is estimated from
2970  the data
2971  * for fitting with user-supplied weights we assume that noise
2972  level in I-th point is inversely proportional to Ith weight.
2973  Coefficient of proportionality is estimated from the data.
2974 
2975 NOTE: we apply small amount of regularization when we invert squared
2976  Jacobian and calculate covariance matrix. It guarantees that
2977  algorithm won't divide by zero during inversion, but skews
2978  error estimates a bit (fractional error is about 10^-9).
2979 
2980  However, we believe that this difference is insignificant for
2981  all practical purposes except for the situation when you want
2982  to compare ALGLIB results with "reference" implementation up
2983  to the last significant digit.
2984 
2985 NOTE: covariance matrix is estimated using correction for degrees
2986  of freedom (covariances are divided by N-M instead of dividing
2987  by N).
2988 
2989  -- ALGLIB --
2990  Copyright 07.09.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
2991 *************************************************************************/
2992 void lsfitlinearc(const real_1d_array &y, const real_2d_array &fmatrix, const real_2d_array &cmatrix, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t m, const ae_int_t k, ae_int_t &info, real_1d_array &c, lsfitreport &rep);
2993 void lsfitlinearc(const real_1d_array &y, const real_2d_array &fmatrix, const real_2d_array &cmatrix, ae_int_t &info, real_1d_array &c, lsfitreport &rep);
2994 
2995 
2996 /*************************************************************************
2997 Weighted nonlinear least squares fitting using function values only.
2998 
2999 Combination of numerical differentiation and secant updates is used to
3000 obtain function Jacobian.
3001 
3002 Nonlinear task min(F(c)) is solved, where
3003 
3004  F(c) = (w[0]*(f(c,x[0])-y[0]))^2 + ... + (w[n-1]*(f(c,x[n-1])-y[n-1]))^2,
3005 
3006  * N is a number of points,
3007  * M is a dimension of a space points belong to,
3008  * K is a dimension of a space of parameters being fitted,
3009  * w is an N-dimensional vector of weight coefficients,
3010  * x is a set of N points, each of them is an M-dimensional vector,
3011  * c is a K-dimensional vector of parameters being fitted
3012 
3013 This subroutine uses only f(c,x[i]).
3014 
3015 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3016  X - array[0..N-1,0..M-1], points (one row = one point)
3017  Y - array[0..N-1], function values.
3018  W - weights, array[0..N-1]
3019  C - array[0..K-1], initial approximation to the solution,
3020  N - number of points, N>1
3021  M - dimension of space
3022  K - number of parameters being fitted
3023  DiffStep- numerical differentiation step;
3024  should not be very small or large;
3025  large = loss of accuracy
3026  small = growth of round-off errors
3027 
3028 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3029  State - structure which stores algorithm state
3030 
3031  -- ALGLIB --
3032  Copyright 18.10.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
3033 *************************************************************************/
3034 void lsfitcreatewf(const real_2d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &w, const real_1d_array &c, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t m, const ae_int_t k, const double diffstep, lsfitstate &state);
3035 void lsfitcreatewf(const real_2d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &w, const real_1d_array &c, const double diffstep, lsfitstate &state);
3036 
3037 
3038 /*************************************************************************
3039 Nonlinear least squares fitting using function values only.
3040 
3041 Combination of numerical differentiation and secant updates is used to
3042 obtain function Jacobian.
3043 
3044 Nonlinear task min(F(c)) is solved, where
3045 
3046  F(c) = (f(c,x[0])-y[0])^2 + ... + (f(c,x[n-1])-y[n-1])^2,
3047 
3048  * N is a number of points,
3049  * M is a dimension of a space points belong to,
3050  * K is a dimension of a space of parameters being fitted,
3051  * w is an N-dimensional vector of weight coefficients,
3052  * x is a set of N points, each of them is an M-dimensional vector,
3053  * c is a K-dimensional vector of parameters being fitted
3054 
3055 This subroutine uses only f(c,x[i]).
3056 
3057 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3058  X - array[0..N-1,0..M-1], points (one row = one point)
3059  Y - array[0..N-1], function values.
3060  C - array[0..K-1], initial approximation to the solution,
3061  N - number of points, N>1
3062  M - dimension of space
3063  K - number of parameters being fitted
3064  DiffStep- numerical differentiation step;
3065  should not be very small or large;
3066  large = loss of accuracy
3067  small = growth of round-off errors
3068 
3069 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3070  State - structure which stores algorithm state
3071 
3072  -- ALGLIB --
3073  Copyright 18.10.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
3074 *************************************************************************/
3075 void lsfitcreatef(const real_2d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &c, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t m, const ae_int_t k, const double diffstep, lsfitstate &state);
3076 void lsfitcreatef(const real_2d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &c, const double diffstep, lsfitstate &state);
3077 
3078 
3079 /*************************************************************************
3080 Weighted nonlinear least squares fitting using gradient only.
3081 
3082 Nonlinear task min(F(c)) is solved, where
3083 
3084  F(c) = (w[0]*(f(c,x[0])-y[0]))^2 + ... + (w[n-1]*(f(c,x[n-1])-y[n-1]))^2,
3085 
3086  * N is a number of points,
3087  * M is a dimension of a space points belong to,
3088  * K is a dimension of a space of parameters being fitted,
3089  * w is an N-dimensional vector of weight coefficients,
3090  * x is a set of N points, each of them is an M-dimensional vector,
3091  * c is a K-dimensional vector of parameters being fitted
3092 
3093 This subroutine uses only f(c,x[i]) and its gradient.
3094 
3095 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3096  X - array[0..N-1,0..M-1], points (one row = one point)
3097  Y - array[0..N-1], function values.
3098  W - weights, array[0..N-1]
3099  C - array[0..K-1], initial approximation to the solution,
3100  N - number of points, N>1
3101  M - dimension of space
3102  K - number of parameters being fitted
3103  CheapFG - boolean flag, which is:
3104  * True if both function and gradient calculation complexity
3105  are less than O(M^2). An improved algorithm can
3106  be used which corresponds to FGJ scheme from
3107  MINLM unit.
3108  * False otherwise.
3109  Standard Jacibian-bases Levenberg-Marquardt algo
3110  will be used (FJ scheme).
3111 
3112 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3113  State - structure which stores algorithm state
3114 
3115 See also:
3116  LSFitResults
3117  LSFitCreateFG (fitting without weights)
3118  LSFitCreateWFGH (fitting using Hessian)
3119  LSFitCreateFGH (fitting using Hessian, without weights)
3120 
3121  -- ALGLIB --
3122  Copyright 17.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
3123 *************************************************************************/
3124 void lsfitcreatewfg(const real_2d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &w, const real_1d_array &c, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t m, const ae_int_t k, const bool cheapfg, lsfitstate &state);
3125 void lsfitcreatewfg(const real_2d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &w, const real_1d_array &c, const bool cheapfg, lsfitstate &state);
3126 
3127 
3128 /*************************************************************************
3129 Nonlinear least squares fitting using gradient only, without individual
3130 weights.
3131 
3132 Nonlinear task min(F(c)) is solved, where
3133 
3134  F(c) = ((f(c,x[0])-y[0]))^2 + ... + ((f(c,x[n-1])-y[n-1]))^2,
3135 
3136  * N is a number of points,
3137  * M is a dimension of a space points belong to,
3138  * K is a dimension of a space of parameters being fitted,
3139  * x is a set of N points, each of them is an M-dimensional vector,
3140  * c is a K-dimensional vector of parameters being fitted
3141 
3142 This subroutine uses only f(c,x[i]) and its gradient.
3143 
3144 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3145  X - array[0..N-1,0..M-1], points (one row = one point)
3146  Y - array[0..N-1], function values.
3147  C - array[0..K-1], initial approximation to the solution,
3148  N - number of points, N>1
3149  M - dimension of space
3150  K - number of parameters being fitted
3151  CheapFG - boolean flag, which is:
3152  * True if both function and gradient calculation complexity
3153  are less than O(M^2). An improved algorithm can
3154  be used which corresponds to FGJ scheme from
3155  MINLM unit.
3156  * False otherwise.
3157  Standard Jacibian-bases Levenberg-Marquardt algo
3158  will be used (FJ scheme).
3159 
3160 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3161  State - structure which stores algorithm state
3162 
3163  -- ALGLIB --
3164  Copyright 17.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
3165 *************************************************************************/
3166 void lsfitcreatefg(const real_2d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &c, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t m, const ae_int_t k, const bool cheapfg, lsfitstate &state);
3167 void lsfitcreatefg(const real_2d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &c, const bool cheapfg, lsfitstate &state);
3168 
3169 
3170 /*************************************************************************
3171 Weighted nonlinear least squares fitting using gradient/Hessian.
3172 
3173 Nonlinear task min(F(c)) is solved, where
3174 
3175  F(c) = (w[0]*(f(c,x[0])-y[0]))^2 + ... + (w[n-1]*(f(c,x[n-1])-y[n-1]))^2,
3176 
3177  * N is a number of points,
3178  * M is a dimension of a space points belong to,
3179  * K is a dimension of a space of parameters being fitted,
3180  * w is an N-dimensional vector of weight coefficients,
3181  * x is a set of N points, each of them is an M-dimensional vector,
3182  * c is a K-dimensional vector of parameters being fitted
3183 
3184 This subroutine uses f(c,x[i]), its gradient and its Hessian.
3185 
3186 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3187  X - array[0..N-1,0..M-1], points (one row = one point)
3188  Y - array[0..N-1], function values.
3189  W - weights, array[0..N-1]
3190  C - array[0..K-1], initial approximation to the solution,
3191  N - number of points, N>1
3192  M - dimension of space
3193  K - number of parameters being fitted
3194 
3195 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3196  State - structure which stores algorithm state
3197 
3198  -- ALGLIB --
3199  Copyright 17.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
3200 *************************************************************************/
3201 void lsfitcreatewfgh(const real_2d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &w, const real_1d_array &c, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t m, const ae_int_t k, lsfitstate &state);
3202 void lsfitcreatewfgh(const real_2d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &w, const real_1d_array &c, lsfitstate &state);
3203 
3204 
3205 /*************************************************************************
3206 Nonlinear least squares fitting using gradient/Hessian, without individial
3207 weights.
3208 
3209 Nonlinear task min(F(c)) is solved, where
3210 
3211  F(c) = ((f(c,x[0])-y[0]))^2 + ... + ((f(c,x[n-1])-y[n-1]))^2,
3212 
3213  * N is a number of points,
3214  * M is a dimension of a space points belong to,
3215  * K is a dimension of a space of parameters being fitted,
3216  * x is a set of N points, each of them is an M-dimensional vector,
3217  * c is a K-dimensional vector of parameters being fitted
3218 
3219 This subroutine uses f(c,x[i]), its gradient and its Hessian.
3220 
3221 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3222  X - array[0..N-1,0..M-1], points (one row = one point)
3223  Y - array[0..N-1], function values.
3224  C - array[0..K-1], initial approximation to the solution,
3225  N - number of points, N>1
3226  M - dimension of space
3227  K - number of parameters being fitted
3228 
3229 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3230  State - structure which stores algorithm state
3231 
3232 
3233  -- ALGLIB --
3234  Copyright 17.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
3235 *************************************************************************/
3236 void lsfitcreatefgh(const real_2d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &c, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t m, const ae_int_t k, lsfitstate &state);
3237 void lsfitcreatefgh(const real_2d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_1d_array &c, lsfitstate &state);
3238 
3239 
3240 /*************************************************************************
3241 Stopping conditions for nonlinear least squares fitting.
3242 
3243 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3244  State - structure which stores algorithm state
3245  EpsF - stopping criterion. Algorithm stops if
3246  |F(k+1)-F(k)| <= EpsF*max{|F(k)|, |F(k+1)|, 1}
3247  EpsX - >=0
3248  The subroutine finishes its work if on k+1-th iteration
3249  the condition |v|<=EpsX is fulfilled, where:
3250  * |.| means Euclidian norm
3251  * v - scaled step vector, v[i]=dx[i]/s[i]
3252  * dx - ste pvector, dx=X(k+1)-X(k)
3253  * s - scaling coefficients set by LSFitSetScale()
3254  MaxIts - maximum number of iterations. If MaxIts=0, the number of
3255  iterations is unlimited. Only Levenberg-Marquardt
3256  iterations are counted (L-BFGS/CG iterations are NOT
3257  counted because their cost is very low compared to that of
3258  LM).
3259 
3260 NOTE
3261 
3262 Passing EpsF=0, EpsX=0 and MaxIts=0 (simultaneously) will lead to automatic
3263 stopping criterion selection (according to the scheme used by MINLM unit).
3264 
3265 
3266  -- ALGLIB --
3267  Copyright 17.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
3268 *************************************************************************/
3269 void lsfitsetcond(const lsfitstate &state, const double epsf, const double epsx, const ae_int_t maxits);
3270 
3271 
3272 /*************************************************************************
3273 This function sets maximum step length
3274 
3275 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3276  State - structure which stores algorithm state
3277  StpMax - maximum step length, >=0. Set StpMax to 0.0, if you don't
3278  want to limit step length.
3279 
3280 Use this subroutine when you optimize target function which contains exp()
3281 or other fast growing functions, and optimization algorithm makes too
3282 large steps which leads to overflow. This function allows us to reject
3283 steps that are too large (and therefore expose us to the possible
3284 overflow) without actually calculating function value at the x+stp*d.
3285 
3286 NOTE: non-zero StpMax leads to moderate performance degradation because
3287 intermediate step of preconditioned L-BFGS optimization is incompatible
3288 with limits on step size.
3289 
3290  -- ALGLIB --
3291  Copyright 02.04.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
3292 *************************************************************************/
3293 void lsfitsetstpmax(const lsfitstate &state, const double stpmax);
3294 
3295 
3296 /*************************************************************************
3297 This function turns on/off reporting.
3298 
3299 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3300  State - structure which stores algorithm state
3301  NeedXRep- whether iteration reports are needed or not
3302 
3303 When reports are needed, State.C (current parameters) and State.F (current
3304 value of fitting function) are reported.
3305 
3306 
3307  -- ALGLIB --
3308  Copyright 15.08.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
3309 *************************************************************************/
3310 void lsfitsetxrep(const lsfitstate &state, const bool needxrep);
3311 
3312 
3313 /*************************************************************************
3314 This function sets scaling coefficients for underlying optimizer.
3315 
3316 ALGLIB optimizers use scaling matrices to test stopping conditions (step
3317 size and gradient are scaled before comparison with tolerances). Scale of
3318 the I-th variable is a translation invariant measure of:
3319 a) "how large" the variable is
3320 b) how large the step should be to make significant changes in the function
3321 
3322 Generally, scale is NOT considered to be a form of preconditioner. But LM
3323 optimizer is unique in that it uses scaling matrix both in the stopping
3324 condition tests and as Marquardt damping factor.
3325 
3326 Proper scaling is very important for the algorithm performance. It is less
3327 important for the quality of results, but still has some influence (it is
3328 easier to converge when variables are properly scaled, so premature
3329 stopping is possible when very badly scalled variables are combined with
3330 relaxed stopping conditions).
3331 
3332 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3333  State - structure stores algorithm state
3334  S - array[N], non-zero scaling coefficients
3335  S[i] may be negative, sign doesn't matter.
3336 
3337  -- ALGLIB --
3338  Copyright 14.01.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
3339 *************************************************************************/
3340 void lsfitsetscale(const lsfitstate &state, const real_1d_array &s);
3341 
3342 
3343 /*************************************************************************
3344 This function sets boundary constraints for underlying optimizer
3345 
3346 Boundary constraints are inactive by default (after initial creation).
3347 They are preserved until explicitly turned off with another SetBC() call.
3348 
3349 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3350  State - structure stores algorithm state
3351  BndL - lower bounds, array[K].
3352  If some (all) variables are unbounded, you may specify
3353  very small number or -INF (latter is recommended because
3354  it will allow solver to use better algorithm).
3355  BndU - upper bounds, array[K].
3356  If some (all) variables are unbounded, you may specify
3357  very large number or +INF (latter is recommended because
3358  it will allow solver to use better algorithm).
3359 
3360 NOTE 1: it is possible to specify BndL[i]=BndU[i]. In this case I-th
3361 variable will be "frozen" at X[i]=BndL[i]=BndU[i].
3362 
3363 NOTE 2: unlike other constrained optimization algorithms, this solver has
3364 following useful properties:
3365 * bound constraints are always satisfied exactly
3366 * function is evaluated only INSIDE area specified by bound constraints
3367 
3368  -- ALGLIB --
3369  Copyright 14.01.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
3370 *************************************************************************/
3371 void lsfitsetbc(const lsfitstate &state, const real_1d_array &bndl, const real_1d_array &bndu);
3372 
3373 
3374 /*************************************************************************
3375 This function provides reverse communication interface
3376 Reverse communication interface is not documented or recommended to use.
3377 See below for functions which provide better documented API
3378 *************************************************************************/
3379 bool lsfititeration(const lsfitstate &state);
3380 
3381 
3382 /*************************************************************************
3383 This family of functions is used to launcn iterations of nonlinear fitter
3384 
3385 These functions accept following parameters:
3386  state - algorithm state
3387  func - callback which calculates function (or merit function)
3388  value func at given point x
3389  grad - callback which calculates function (or merit function)
3390  value func and gradient grad at given point x
3391  hess - callback which calculates function (or merit function)
3392  value func, gradient grad and Hessian hess at given point x
3393  rep - optional callback which is called after each iteration
3394  can be NULL
3395  ptr - optional pointer which is passed to func/grad/hess/jac/rep
3396  can be NULL
3397 
3398 NOTES:
3399 
3400 1. this algorithm is somewhat unusual because it works with parameterized
3401  function f(C,X), where X is a function argument (we have many points
3402  which are characterized by different argument values), and C is a
3403  parameter to fit.
3404 
3405  For example, if we want to do linear fit by f(c0,c1,x) = c0*x+c1, then
3406  x will be argument, and {c0,c1} will be parameters.
3407 
3408  It is important to understand that this algorithm finds minimum in the
3409  space of function PARAMETERS (not arguments), so it needs derivatives
3410  of f() with respect to C, not X.
3411 
3412  In the example above it will need f=c0*x+c1 and {df/dc0,df/dc1} = {x,1}
3413  instead of {df/dx} = {c0}.
3414 
3415 2. Callback functions accept C as the first parameter, and X as the second
3416 
3417 3. If state was created with LSFitCreateFG(), algorithm needs just
3418  function and its gradient, but if state was created with
3419  LSFitCreateFGH(), algorithm will need function, gradient and Hessian.
3420 
3421  According to the said above, there ase several versions of this
3422  function, which accept different sets of callbacks.
3423 
3424  This flexibility opens way to subtle errors - you may create state with
3425  LSFitCreateFGH() (optimization using Hessian), but call function which
3426  does not accept Hessian. So when algorithm will request Hessian, there
3427  will be no callback to call. In this case exception will be thrown.
3428 
3429  Be careful to avoid such errors because there is no way to find them at
3430  compile time - you can see them at runtime only.
3431 
3432  -- ALGLIB --
3433  Copyright 17.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
3434 
3435 *************************************************************************/
3436 void lsfitfit(lsfitstate &state,
3437  void (*func)(const real_1d_array &c, const real_1d_array &x, double &func, void *ptr),
3438  void (*rep)(const real_1d_array &c, double func, void *ptr) = NULL,
3439  void *ptr = NULL);
3440 void lsfitfit(lsfitstate &state,
3441  void (*func)(const real_1d_array &c, const real_1d_array &x, double &func, void *ptr),
3442  void (*grad)(const real_1d_array &c, const real_1d_array &x, double &func, real_1d_array &grad, void *ptr),
3443  void (*rep)(const real_1d_array &c, double func, void *ptr) = NULL,
3444  void *ptr = NULL);
3445 void lsfitfit(lsfitstate &state,
3446  void (*func)(const real_1d_array &c, const real_1d_array &x, double &func, void *ptr),
3447  void (*grad)(const real_1d_array &c, const real_1d_array &x, double &func, real_1d_array &grad, void *ptr),
3448  void (*hess)(const real_1d_array &c, const real_1d_array &x, double &func, real_1d_array &grad, real_2d_array &hess, void *ptr),
3449  void (*rep)(const real_1d_array &c, double func, void *ptr) = NULL,
3450  void *ptr = NULL);
3451 
3452 
3453 /*************************************************************************
3454 Nonlinear least squares fitting results.
3455 
3456 Called after return from LSFitFit().
3457 
3458 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3459  State - algorithm state
3460 
3461 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3462  Info - completion code:
3463  * -7 gradient verification failed.
3464  See LSFitSetGradientCheck() for more information.
3465  * 1 relative function improvement is no more than
3466  EpsF.
3467  * 2 relative step is no more than EpsX.
3468  * 4 gradient norm is no more than EpsG
3469  * 5 MaxIts steps was taken
3470  * 7 stopping conditions are too stringent,
3471  further improvement is impossible
3472  C - array[0..K-1], solution
3473  Rep - optimization report. On success following fields are set:
3474  * R2 non-adjusted coefficient of determination
3475  (non-weighted)
3476  * RMSError rms error on the (X,Y).
3477  * AvgError average error on the (X,Y).
3478  * AvgRelError average relative error on the non-zero Y
3479  * MaxError maximum error
3480  NON-WEIGHTED ERRORS ARE CALCULATED
3481  * WRMSError weighted rms error on the (X,Y).
3482 
3483 ERRORS IN PARAMETERS
3484 
3485 This solver also calculates different kinds of errors in parameters and
3486 fills corresponding fields of report:
3487 * Rep.CovPar covariance matrix for parameters, array[K,K].
3488 * Rep.ErrPar errors in parameters, array[K],
3489  errpar = sqrt(diag(CovPar))
3490 * Rep.ErrCurve vector of fit errors - standard deviations of empirical
3491  best-fit curve from "ideal" best-fit curve built with
3492  infinite number of samples, array[N].
3493  errcurve = sqrt(diag(J*CovPar*J')),
3494  where J is Jacobian matrix.
3495 * Rep.Noise vector of per-point estimates of noise, array[N]
3496 
3497 IMPORTANT: errors in parameters are calculated without taking into
3498  account boundary/linear constraints! Presence of constraints
3499  changes distribution of errors, but there is no easy way to
3500  account for constraints when you calculate covariance matrix.
3501 
3502 NOTE: noise in the data is estimated as follows:
3503  * for fitting without user-supplied weights all points are
3504  assumed to have same level of noise, which is estimated from
3505  the data
3506  * for fitting with user-supplied weights we assume that noise
3507  level in I-th point is inversely proportional to Ith weight.
3508  Coefficient of proportionality is estimated from the data.
3509 
3510 NOTE: we apply small amount of regularization when we invert squared
3511  Jacobian and calculate covariance matrix. It guarantees that
3512  algorithm won't divide by zero during inversion, but skews
3513  error estimates a bit (fractional error is about 10^-9).
3514 
3515  However, we believe that this difference is insignificant for
3516  all practical purposes except for the situation when you want
3517  to compare ALGLIB results with "reference" implementation up
3518  to the last significant digit.
3519 
3520 NOTE: covariance matrix is estimated using correction for degrees
3521  of freedom (covariances are divided by N-M instead of dividing
3522  by N).
3523 
3524  -- ALGLIB --
3525  Copyright 17.08.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
3526 *************************************************************************/
3527 void lsfitresults(const lsfitstate &state, ae_int_t &info, real_1d_array &c, lsfitreport &rep);
3528 
3529 
3530 /*************************************************************************
3531 This subroutine turns on verification of the user-supplied analytic
3532 gradient:
3533 * user calls this subroutine before fitting begins
3534 * LSFitFit() is called
3535 * prior to actual fitting, for each point in data set X_i and each
3536  component of parameters being fited C_j algorithm performs following
3537  steps:
3538  * two trial steps are made to C_j-TestStep*S[j] and C_j+TestStep*S[j],
3539  where C_j is j-th parameter and S[j] is a scale of j-th parameter
3540  * if needed, steps are bounded with respect to constraints on C[]
3541  * F(X_i|C) is evaluated at these trial points
3542  * we perform one more evaluation in the middle point of the interval
3543  * we build cubic model using function values and derivatives at trial
3544  points and we compare its prediction with actual value in the middle
3545  point
3546  * in case difference between prediction and actual value is higher than
3547  some predetermined threshold, algorithm stops with completion code -7;
3548  Rep.VarIdx is set to index of the parameter with incorrect derivative.
3549 * after verification is over, algorithm proceeds to the actual optimization.
3550 
3551 NOTE 1: verification needs N*K (points count * parameters count) gradient
3552  evaluations. It is very costly and you should use it only for low
3553  dimensional problems, when you want to be sure that you've
3554  correctly calculated analytic derivatives. You should not use it
3555  in the production code (unless you want to check derivatives
3556  provided by some third party).
3557 
3558 NOTE 2: you should carefully choose TestStep. Value which is too large
3559  (so large that function behaviour is significantly non-cubic) will
3560  lead to false alarms. You may use different step for different
3561  parameters by means of setting scale with LSFitSetScale().
3562 
3563 NOTE 3: this function may lead to false positives. In case it reports that
3564  I-th derivative was calculated incorrectly, you may decrease test
3565  step and try one more time - maybe your function changes too
3566  sharply and your step is too large for such rapidly chanding
3567  function.
3568 
3569 NOTE 4: this function works only for optimizers created with LSFitCreateWFG()
3570  or LSFitCreateFG() constructors.
3571 
3572 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3573  State - structure used to store algorithm state
3574  TestStep - verification step:
3575  * TestStep=0 turns verification off
3576  * TestStep>0 activates verification
3577 
3578  -- ALGLIB --
3579  Copyright 15.06.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
3580 *************************************************************************/
3581 void lsfitsetgradientcheck(const lsfitstate &state, const double teststep);
3582 
3583 /*************************************************************************
3584 This function builds non-periodic 2-dimensional parametric spline which
3585 starts at (X[0],Y[0]) and ends at (X[N-1],Y[N-1]).
3586 
3587 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3588  XY - points, array[0..N-1,0..1].
3589  XY[I,0:1] corresponds to the Ith point.
3590  Order of points is important!
3591  N - points count, N>=5 for Akima splines, N>=2 for other types of
3592  splines.
3593  ST - spline type:
3594  * 0 Akima spline
3595  * 1 parabolically terminated Catmull-Rom spline (Tension=0)
3596  * 2 parabolically terminated cubic spline
3597  PT - parameterization type:
3598  * 0 uniform
3599  * 1 chord length
3600  * 2 centripetal
3601 
3602 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3603  P - parametric spline interpolant
3604 
3605 
3606 NOTES:
3607 * this function assumes that there all consequent points are distinct.
3608  I.e. (x0,y0)<>(x1,y1), (x1,y1)<>(x2,y2), (x2,y2)<>(x3,y3) and so on.
3609  However, non-consequent points may coincide, i.e. we can have (x0,y0)=
3610  =(x2,y2).
3611 
3612  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3613  Copyright 28.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
3614 *************************************************************************/
3615 void pspline2build(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t st, const ae_int_t pt, pspline2interpolant &p);
3616 
3617 
3618 /*************************************************************************
3619 This function builds non-periodic 3-dimensional parametric spline which
3620 starts at (X[0],Y[0],Z[0]) and ends at (X[N-1],Y[N-1],Z[N-1]).
3621 
3622 Same as PSpline2Build() function, but for 3D, so we won't duplicate its
3623 description here.
3624 
3625  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3626  Copyright 28.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
3627 *************************************************************************/
3628 void pspline3build(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t st, const ae_int_t pt, pspline3interpolant &p);
3629 
3630 
3631 /*************************************************************************
3632 This function builds periodic 2-dimensional parametric spline which
3633 starts at (X[0],Y[0]), goes through all points to (X[N-1],Y[N-1]) and then
3634 back to (X[0],Y[0]).
3635 
3636 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3637  XY - points, array[0..N-1,0..1].
3638  XY[I,0:1] corresponds to the Ith point.
3639  XY[N-1,0:1] must be different from XY[0,0:1].
3640  Order of points is important!
3641  N - points count, N>=3 for other types of splines.
3642  ST - spline type:
3643  * 1 Catmull-Rom spline (Tension=0) with cyclic boundary conditions
3644  * 2 cubic spline with cyclic boundary conditions
3645  PT - parameterization type:
3646  * 0 uniform
3647  * 1 chord length
3648  * 2 centripetal
3649 
3650 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3651  P - parametric spline interpolant
3652 
3653 
3654 NOTES:
3655 * this function assumes that there all consequent points are distinct.
3656  I.e. (x0,y0)<>(x1,y1), (x1,y1)<>(x2,y2), (x2,y2)<>(x3,y3) and so on.
3657  However, non-consequent points may coincide, i.e. we can have (x0,y0)=
3658  =(x2,y2).
3659 * last point of sequence is NOT equal to the first point. You shouldn't
3660  make curve "explicitly periodic" by making them equal.
3661 
3662  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3663  Copyright 28.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
3664 *************************************************************************/
3665 void pspline2buildperiodic(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t st, const ae_int_t pt, pspline2interpolant &p);
3666 
3667 
3668 /*************************************************************************
3669 This function builds periodic 3-dimensional parametric spline which
3670 starts at (X[0],Y[0],Z[0]), goes through all points to (X[N-1],Y[N-1],Z[N-1])
3671 and then back to (X[0],Y[0],Z[0]).
3672 
3673 Same as PSpline2Build() function, but for 3D, so we won't duplicate its
3674 description here.
3675 
3676  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3677  Copyright 28.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
3678 *************************************************************************/
3679 void pspline3buildperiodic(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t st, const ae_int_t pt, pspline3interpolant &p);
3680 
3681 
3682 /*************************************************************************
3683 This function returns vector of parameter values correspoding to points.
3684 
3685 I.e. for P created from (X[0],Y[0])...(X[N-1],Y[N-1]) and U=TValues(P) we
3686 have
3687  (X[0],Y[0]) = PSpline2Calc(P,U[0]),
3688  (X[1],Y[1]) = PSpline2Calc(P,U[1]),
3689  (X[2],Y[2]) = PSpline2Calc(P,U[2]),
3690  ...
3691 
3692 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3693  P - parametric spline interpolant
3694 
3695 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3696  N - array size
3697  T - array[0..N-1]
3698 
3699 
3700 NOTES:
3701 * for non-periodic splines U[0]=0, U[0]<U[1]<...<U[N-1], U[N-1]=1
3702 * for periodic splines U[0]=0, U[0]<U[1]<...<U[N-1], U[N-1]<1
3703 
3704  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3705  Copyright 28.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
3706 *************************************************************************/
3707 void pspline2parametervalues(const pspline2interpolant &p, ae_int_t &n, real_1d_array &t);
3708 
3709 
3710 /*************************************************************************
3711 This function returns vector of parameter values correspoding to points.
3712 
3713 Same as PSpline2ParameterValues(), but for 3D.
3714 
3715  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3716  Copyright 28.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
3717 *************************************************************************/
3718 void pspline3parametervalues(const pspline3interpolant &p, ae_int_t &n, real_1d_array &t);
3719 
3720 
3721 /*************************************************************************
3722 This function calculates the value of the parametric spline for a given
3723 value of parameter T
3724 
3725 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3726  P - parametric spline interpolant
3727  T - point:
3728  * T in [0,1] corresponds to interval spanned by points
3729  * for non-periodic splines T<0 (or T>1) correspond to parts of
3730  the curve before the first (after the last) point
3731  * for periodic splines T<0 (or T>1) are projected into [0,1]
3732  by making T=T-floor(T).
3733 
3734 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3735  X - X-position
3736  Y - Y-position
3737 
3738 
3739  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3740  Copyright 28.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
3741 *************************************************************************/
3742 void pspline2calc(const pspline2interpolant &p, const double t, double &x, double &y);
3743 
3744 
3745 /*************************************************************************
3746 This function calculates the value of the parametric spline for a given
3747 value of parameter T.
3748 
3749 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3750  P - parametric spline interpolant
3751  T - point:
3752  * T in [0,1] corresponds to interval spanned by points
3753  * for non-periodic splines T<0 (or T>1) correspond to parts of
3754  the curve before the first (after the last) point
3755  * for periodic splines T<0 (or T>1) are projected into [0,1]
3756  by making T=T-floor(T).
3757 
3758 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3759  X - X-position
3760  Y - Y-position
3761  Z - Z-position
3762 
3763 
3764  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3765  Copyright 28.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
3766 *************************************************************************/
3767 void pspline3calc(const pspline3interpolant &p, const double t, double &x, double &y, double &z);
3768 
3769 
3770 /*************************************************************************
3771 This function calculates tangent vector for a given value of parameter T
3772 
3773 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3774  P - parametric spline interpolant
3775  T - point:
3776  * T in [0,1] corresponds to interval spanned by points
3777  * for non-periodic splines T<0 (or T>1) correspond to parts of
3778  the curve before the first (after the last) point
3779  * for periodic splines T<0 (or T>1) are projected into [0,1]
3780  by making T=T-floor(T).
3781 
3782 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3783  X - X-component of tangent vector (normalized)
3784  Y - Y-component of tangent vector (normalized)
3785 
3786 NOTE:
3787  X^2+Y^2 is either 1 (for non-zero tangent vector) or 0.
3788 
3789 
3790  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3791  Copyright 28.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
3792 *************************************************************************/
3793 void pspline2tangent(const pspline2interpolant &p, const double t, double &x, double &y);
3794 
3795 
3796 /*************************************************************************
3797 This function calculates tangent vector for a given value of parameter T
3798 
3799 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3800  P - parametric spline interpolant
3801  T - point:
3802  * T in [0,1] corresponds to interval spanned by points
3803  * for non-periodic splines T<0 (or T>1) correspond to parts of
3804  the curve before the first (after the last) point
3805  * for periodic splines T<0 (or T>1) are projected into [0,1]
3806  by making T=T-floor(T).
3807 
3808 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3809  X - X-component of tangent vector (normalized)
3810  Y - Y-component of tangent vector (normalized)
3811  Z - Z-component of tangent vector (normalized)
3812 
3813 NOTE:
3814  X^2+Y^2+Z^2 is either 1 (for non-zero tangent vector) or 0.
3815 
3816 
3817  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3818  Copyright 28.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
3819 *************************************************************************/
3820 void pspline3tangent(const pspline3interpolant &p, const double t, double &x, double &y, double &z);
3821 
3822 
3823 /*************************************************************************
3824 This function calculates derivative, i.e. it returns (dX/dT,dY/dT).
3825 
3826 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3827  P - parametric spline interpolant
3828  T - point:
3829  * T in [0,1] corresponds to interval spanned by points
3830  * for non-periodic splines T<0 (or T>1) correspond to parts of
3831  the curve before the first (after the last) point
3832  * for periodic splines T<0 (or T>1) are projected into [0,1]
3833  by making T=T-floor(T).
3834 
3835 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3836  X - X-value
3837  DX - X-derivative
3838  Y - Y-value
3839  DY - Y-derivative
3840 
3841 
3842  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3843  Copyright 28.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
3844 *************************************************************************/
3845 void pspline2diff(const pspline2interpolant &p, const double t, double &x, double &dx, double &y, double &dy);
3846 
3847 
3848 /*************************************************************************
3849 This function calculates derivative, i.e. it returns (dX/dT,dY/dT,dZ/dT).
3850 
3851 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3852  P - parametric spline interpolant
3853  T - point:
3854  * T in [0,1] corresponds to interval spanned by points
3855  * for non-periodic splines T<0 (or T>1) correspond to parts of
3856  the curve before the first (after the last) point
3857  * for periodic splines T<0 (or T>1) are projected into [0,1]
3858  by making T=T-floor(T).
3859 
3860 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3861  X - X-value
3862  DX - X-derivative
3863  Y - Y-value
3864  DY - Y-derivative
3865  Z - Z-value
3866  DZ - Z-derivative
3867 
3868 
3869  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3870  Copyright 28.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
3871 *************************************************************************/
3872 void pspline3diff(const pspline3interpolant &p, const double t, double &x, double &dx, double &y, double &dy, double &z, double &dz);
3873 
3874 
3875 /*************************************************************************
3876 This function calculates first and second derivative with respect to T.
3877 
3878 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3879  P - parametric spline interpolant
3880  T - point:
3881  * T in [0,1] corresponds to interval spanned by points
3882  * for non-periodic splines T<0 (or T>1) correspond to parts of
3883  the curve before the first (after the last) point
3884  * for periodic splines T<0 (or T>1) are projected into [0,1]
3885  by making T=T-floor(T).
3886 
3887 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3888  X - X-value
3889  DX - derivative
3890  D2X - second derivative
3891  Y - Y-value
3892  DY - derivative
3893  D2Y - second derivative
3894 
3895 
3896  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3897  Copyright 28.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
3898 *************************************************************************/
3899 void pspline2diff2(const pspline2interpolant &p, const double t, double &x, double &dx, double &d2x, double &y, double &dy, double &d2y);
3900 
3901 
3902 /*************************************************************************
3903 This function calculates first and second derivative with respect to T.
3904 
3905 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3906  P - parametric spline interpolant
3907  T - point:
3908  * T in [0,1] corresponds to interval spanned by points
3909  * for non-periodic splines T<0 (or T>1) correspond to parts of
3910  the curve before the first (after the last) point
3911  * for periodic splines T<0 (or T>1) are projected into [0,1]
3912  by making T=T-floor(T).
3913 
3914 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3915  X - X-value
3916  DX - derivative
3917  D2X - second derivative
3918  Y - Y-value
3919  DY - derivative
3920  D2Y - second derivative
3921  Z - Z-value
3922  DZ - derivative
3923  D2Z - second derivative
3924 
3925 
3926  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3927  Copyright 28.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
3928 *************************************************************************/
3929 void pspline3diff2(const pspline3interpolant &p, const double t, double &x, double &dx, double &d2x, double &y, double &dy, double &d2y, double &z, double &dz, double &d2z);
3930 
3931 
3932 /*************************************************************************
3933 This function calculates arc length, i.e. length of curve between t=a
3934 and t=b.
3935 
3936 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3937  P - parametric spline interpolant
3938  A,B - parameter values corresponding to arc ends:
3939  * B>A will result in positive length returned
3940  * B<A will result in negative length returned
3941 
3942 RESULT:
3943  length of arc starting at T=A and ending at T=B.
3944 
3945 
3946  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3947  Copyright 30.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
3948 *************************************************************************/
3949 double pspline2arclength(const pspline2interpolant &p, const double a, const double b);
3950 
3951 
3952 /*************************************************************************
3953 This function calculates arc length, i.e. length of curve between t=a
3954 and t=b.
3955 
3956 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3957  P - parametric spline interpolant
3958  A,B - parameter values corresponding to arc ends:
3959  * B>A will result in positive length returned
3960  * B<A will result in negative length returned
3961 
3962 RESULT:
3963  length of arc starting at T=A and ending at T=B.
3964 
3965 
3966  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
3967  Copyright 30.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
3968 *************************************************************************/
3969 double pspline3arclength(const pspline3interpolant &p, const double a, const double b);
3970 
3971 /*************************************************************************
3972 This function serializes data structure to string.
3973 
3974 Important properties of s_out:
3975 * it contains alphanumeric characters, dots, underscores, minus signs
3976 * these symbols are grouped into words, which are separated by spaces
3977  and Windows-style (CR+LF) newlines
3978 * although serializer uses spaces and CR+LF as separators, you can
3979  replace any separator character by arbitrary combination of spaces,
3980  tabs, Windows or Unix newlines. It allows flexible reformatting of
3981  the string in case you want to include it into text or XML file.
3982  But you should not insert separators into the middle of the "words"
3983  nor you should change case of letters.
3984 * s_out can be freely moved between 32-bit and 64-bit systems, little
3985  and big endian machines, and so on. You can serialize structure on
3986  32-bit machine and unserialize it on 64-bit one (or vice versa), or
3987  serialize it on SPARC and unserialize on x86. You can also
3988  serialize it in C++ version of ALGLIB and unserialize in C# one,
3989  and vice versa.
3990 *************************************************************************/
3991 void rbfserialize(rbfmodel &obj, std::string &s_out);
3992 
3993 
3994 /*************************************************************************
3995 This function unserializes data structure from string.
3996 *************************************************************************/
3997 void rbfunserialize(std::string &s_in, rbfmodel &obj);
3998 
3999
