4000 /*************************************************************************
4001 This function creates RBF model for a scalar (NY=1) or vector (NY>1)
4002 function in a NX-dimensional space (NX=2 or NX=3).
4003 
4004 Newly created model is empty. It can be used for interpolation right after
4005 creation, but it just returns zeros. You have to add points to the model,
4006 tune interpolation settings, and then call model construction function
4007 RBFBuildModel() which will update model according to your specification.
4008 
4009 USAGE:
4010 1. User creates model with RBFCreate()
4011 2. User adds dataset with RBFSetPoints() (points do NOT have to be on a
4012  regular grid)
4013 3. (OPTIONAL) User chooses polynomial term by calling:
4014  * RBFLinTerm() to set linear term
4015  * RBFConstTerm() to set constant term
4016  * RBFZeroTerm() to set zero term
4017  By default, linear term is used.
4018 4. User chooses specific RBF algorithm to use: either QNN (RBFSetAlgoQNN)
4019  or ML (RBFSetAlgoMultiLayer).
4020 5. User calls RBFBuildModel() function which rebuilds model according to
4021  the specification
4022 6. User may call RBFCalc() to calculate model value at the specified point,
4023  RBFGridCalc() to calculate model values at the points of the regular
4024  grid. User may extract model coefficients with RBFUnpack() call.
4025 
4026 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4027  NX - dimension of the space, NX=2 or NX=3
4028  NY - function dimension, NY>=1
4029 
4030 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4031  S - RBF model (initially equals to zero)
4032 
4033 NOTE 1: memory requirements. RBF models require amount of memory which is
4034  proportional to the number of data points. Memory is allocated
4035  during model construction, but most of this memory is freed after
4036  model coefficients are calculated.
4037 
4038  Some approximate estimates for N centers with default settings are
4039  given below:
4040  * about 250*N*(sizeof(double)+2*sizeof(int)) bytes of memory is
4041  needed during model construction stage.
4042  * about 15*N*sizeof(double) bytes is needed after model is built.
4043  For example, for N=100000 we may need 0.6 GB of memory to build
4044  model, but just about 0.012 GB to store it.
4045 
4046  -- ALGLIB --
4047  Copyright 13.12.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
4048 *************************************************************************/
4049 void rbfcreate(const ae_int_t nx, const ae_int_t ny, rbfmodel &s);
4050 
4051 
4052 /*************************************************************************
4053 This function adds dataset.
4054 
4055 This function overrides results of the previous calls, i.e. multiple calls
4056 of this function will result in only the last set being added.
4057 
4058 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4059  S - RBF model, initialized by RBFCreate() call.
4060  XY - points, array[N,NX+NY]. One row corresponds to one point
4061  in the dataset. First NX elements are coordinates, next
4062  NY elements are function values. Array may be larger than
4063  specific, in this case only leading [N,NX+NY] elements
4064  will be used.
4065  N - number of points in the dataset
4066 
4067 After you've added dataset and (optionally) tuned algorithm settings you
4068 should call RBFBuildModel() in order to build a model for you.
4069 
4070 NOTE: this function has some serialization-related subtleties. We
4071  recommend you to study serialization examples from ALGLIB Reference
4072  Manual if you want to perform serialization of your models.
4073 
4074 
4075  -- ALGLIB --
4076  Copyright 13.12.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
4077 *************************************************************************/
4078 void rbfsetpoints(const rbfmodel &s, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t n);
4079 void rbfsetpoints(const rbfmodel &s, const real_2d_array &xy);
4080 
4081 
4082 /*************************************************************************
4083 This function sets RBF interpolation algorithm. ALGLIB supports several
4084 RBF algorithms with different properties.
4085 
4086 This algorithm is called RBF-QNN and it is good for point sets with
4087 following properties:
4088 a) all points are distinct
4089 b) all points are well separated.
4090 c) points distribution is approximately uniform. There is no "contour
4091  lines", clusters of points, or other small-scale structures.
4092 
4093 Algorithm description:
4094 1) interpolation centers are allocated to data points
4095 2) interpolation radii are calculated as distances to the nearest centers
4096  times Q coefficient (where Q is a value from [0.75,1.50]).
4097 3) after performing (2) radii are transformed in order to avoid situation
4098  when single outlier has very large radius and influences many points
4099  across all dataset. Transformation has following form:
4100  new_r[i] = min(r[i],Z*median(r[]))
4101  where r[i] is I-th radius, median() is a median radius across entire
4102  dataset, Z is user-specified value which controls amount of deviation
4103  from median radius.
4104 
4105 When (a) is violated, we will be unable to build RBF model. When (b) or
4106 (c) are violated, model will be built, but interpolation quality will be
4107 low. See http://www.alglib.net/interpolation/ for more information on this
4108 subject.
4109 
4110 This algorithm is used by default.
4111 
4112 Additional Q parameter controls smoothness properties of the RBF basis:
4113 * Q<0.75 will give perfectly conditioned basis, but terrible smoothness
4114  properties (RBF interpolant will have sharp peaks around function values)
4115 * Q around 1.0 gives good balance between smoothness and condition number
4116 * Q>1.5 will lead to badly conditioned systems and slow convergence of the
4117  underlying linear solver (although smoothness will be very good)
4118 * Q>2.0 will effectively make optimizer useless because it won't converge
4119  within reasonable amount of iterations. It is possible to set such large
4120  Q, but it is advised not to do so.
4121 
4122 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4123  S - RBF model, initialized by RBFCreate() call
4124  Q - Q parameter, Q>0, recommended value - 1.0
4125  Z - Z parameter, Z>0, recommended value - 5.0
4126 
4127 NOTE: this function has some serialization-related subtleties. We
4128  recommend you to study serialization examples from ALGLIB Reference
4129  Manual if you want to perform serialization of your models.
4130 
4131 
4132  -- ALGLIB --
4133  Copyright 13.12.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
4134 *************************************************************************/
4135 void rbfsetalgoqnn(const rbfmodel &s, const double q, const double z);
4136 void rbfsetalgoqnn(const rbfmodel &s);
4137 
4138 
4139 /*************************************************************************
4140 This function sets RBF interpolation algorithm. ALGLIB supports several
4141 RBF algorithms with different properties.
4142 
4143 This algorithm is called RBF-ML. It builds multilayer RBF model, i.e.
4144 model with subsequently decreasing radii, which allows us to combine
4145 smoothness (due to large radii of the first layers) with exactness (due
4146 to small radii of the last layers) and fast convergence.
4147 
4148 Internally RBF-ML uses many different means of acceleration, from sparse
4149 matrices to KD-trees, which results in algorithm whose working time is
4150 roughly proportional to N*log(N)*Density*RBase^2*NLayers, where N is a
4151 number of points, Density is an average density if points per unit of the
4152 interpolation space, RBase is an initial radius, NLayers is a number of
4153 layers.
4154 
4155 RBF-ML is good for following kinds of interpolation problems:
4156 1. "exact" problems (perfect fit) with well separated points
4157 2. least squares problems with arbitrary distribution of points (algorithm
4158  gives perfect fit where it is possible, and resorts to least squares
4159  fit in the hard areas).
4160 3. noisy problems where we want to apply some controlled amount of
4161  smoothing.
4162 
4163 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4164  S - RBF model, initialized by RBFCreate() call
4165  RBase - RBase parameter, RBase>0
4166  NLayers - NLayers parameter, NLayers>0, recommended value to start
4167  with - about 5.
4168  LambdaV - regularization value, can be useful when solving problem
4169  in the least squares sense. Optimal lambda is problem-
4170  dependent and require trial and error. In our experience,
4171  good lambda can be as large as 0.1, and you can use 0.001
4172  as initial guess.
4173  Default value - 0.01, which is used when LambdaV is not
4174  given. You can specify zero value, but it is not
4175  recommended to do so.
4176 
4177 TUNING ALGORITHM
4178 
4179 In order to use this algorithm you have to choose three parameters:
4180 * initial radius RBase
4181 * number of layers in the model NLayers
4182 * regularization coefficient LambdaV
4183 
4184 Initial radius is easy to choose - you can pick any number several times
4185 larger than the average distance between points. Algorithm won't break
4186 down if you choose radius which is too large (model construction time will
4187 increase, but model will be built correctly).
4188 
4189 Choose such number of layers that RLast=RBase/2^(NLayers-1) (radius used
4190 by the last layer) will be smaller than the typical distance between
4191 points. In case model error is too large, you can increase number of
4192 layers. Having more layers will make model construction and evaluation
4193 proportionally slower, but it will allow you to have model which precisely
4194 fits your data. From the other side, if you want to suppress noise, you
4195 can DECREASE number of layers to make your model less flexible.
4196 
4197 Regularization coefficient LambdaV controls smoothness of the individual
4198 models built for each layer. We recommend you to use default value in case
4199 you don't want to tune this parameter, because having non-zero LambdaV
4200 accelerates and stabilizes internal iterative algorithm. In case you want
4201 to suppress noise you can use LambdaV as additional parameter (larger
4202 value = more smoothness) to tune.
4203 
4204 TYPICAL ERRORS
4205 
4206 1. Using initial radius which is too large. Memory requirements of the
4207  RBF-ML are roughly proportional to N*Density*RBase^2 (where Density is
4208  an average density of points per unit of the interpolation space). In
4209  the extreme case of the very large RBase we will need O(N^2) units of
4210  memory - and many layers in order to decrease radius to some reasonably
4211  small value.
4212 
4213 2. Using too small number of layers - RBF models with large radius are not
4214  flexible enough to reproduce small variations in the target function.
4215  You need many layers with different radii, from large to small, in
4216  order to have good model.
4217 
4218 3. Using initial radius which is too small. You will get model with
4219  "holes" in the areas which are too far away from interpolation centers.
4220  However, algorithm will work correctly (and quickly) in this case.
4221 
4222 4. Using too many layers - you will get too large and too slow model. This
4223  model will perfectly reproduce your function, but maybe you will be
4224  able to achieve similar results with less layers (and less memory).
4225 
4226  -- ALGLIB --
4227  Copyright 02.03.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
4228 *************************************************************************/
4229 void rbfsetalgomultilayer(const rbfmodel &s, const double rbase, const ae_int_t nlayers, const double lambdav);
4230 void rbfsetalgomultilayer(const rbfmodel &s, const double rbase, const ae_int_t nlayers);
4231 
4232 
4233 /*************************************************************************
4234 This function sets linear term (model is a sum of radial basis functions
4235 plus linear polynomial). This function won't have effect until next call
4236 to RBFBuildModel().
4237 
4238 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4239  S - RBF model, initialized by RBFCreate() call
4240 
4241 NOTE: this function has some serialization-related subtleties. We
4242  recommend you to study serialization examples from ALGLIB Reference
4243  Manual if you want to perform serialization of your models.
4244 
4245  -- ALGLIB --
4246  Copyright 13.12.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
4247 *************************************************************************/
4248 void rbfsetlinterm(const rbfmodel &s);
4249 
4250 
4251 /*************************************************************************
4252 This function sets constant term (model is a sum of radial basis functions
4253 plus constant). This function won't have effect until next call to
4254 RBFBuildModel().
4255 
4256 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4257  S - RBF model, initialized by RBFCreate() call
4258 
4259 NOTE: this function has some serialization-related subtleties. We
4260  recommend you to study serialization examples from ALGLIB Reference
4261  Manual if you want to perform serialization of your models.
4262 
4263  -- ALGLIB --
4264  Copyright 13.12.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
4265 *************************************************************************/
4266 void rbfsetconstterm(const rbfmodel &s);
4267 
4268 
4269 /*************************************************************************
4270 This function sets zero term (model is a sum of radial basis functions
4271 without polynomial term). This function won't have effect until next call
4272 to RBFBuildModel().
4273 
4274 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4275  S - RBF model, initialized by RBFCreate() call
4276 
4277 NOTE: this function has some serialization-related subtleties. We
4278  recommend you to study serialization examples from ALGLIB Reference
4279  Manual if you want to perform serialization of your models.
4280 
4281  -- ALGLIB --
4282  Copyright 13.12.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
4283 *************************************************************************/
4284 void rbfsetzeroterm(const rbfmodel &s);
4285 
4286 
4287 /*************************************************************************
4288 This function builds RBF model and returns report (contains some
4289 information which can be used for evaluation of the algorithm properties).
4290 
4291 Call to this function modifies RBF model by calculating its centers/radii/
4292 weights and saving them into RBFModel structure. Initially RBFModel
4293 contain zero coefficients, but after call to this function we will have
4294 coefficients which were calculated in order to fit our dataset.
4295 
4296 After you called this function you can call RBFCalc(), RBFGridCalc() and
4297 other model calculation functions.
4298 
4299 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4300  S - RBF model, initialized by RBFCreate() call
4301  Rep - report:
4302  * Rep.TerminationType:
4303  * -5 - non-distinct basis function centers were detected,
4304  interpolation aborted
4305  * -4 - nonconvergence of the internal SVD solver
4306  * 1 - successful termination
4307  Fields are used for debugging purposes:
4308  * Rep.IterationsCount - iterations count of the LSQR solver
4309  * Rep.NMV - number of matrix-vector products
4310  * Rep.ARows - rows count for the system matrix
4311  * Rep.ACols - columns count for the system matrix
4312  * Rep.ANNZ - number of significantly non-zero elements
4313  (elements above some algorithm-determined threshold)
4314 
4315 NOTE: failure to build model will leave current state of the structure
4316 unchanged.
4317 
4318  -- ALGLIB --
4319  Copyright 13.12.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
4320 *************************************************************************/
4321 void rbfbuildmodel(const rbfmodel &s, rbfreport &rep);
4322 
4323 
4324 /*************************************************************************
4325 This function calculates values of the RBF model in the given point.
4326 
4327 This function should be used when we have NY=1 (scalar function) and NX=2
4328 (2-dimensional space). If you have 3-dimensional space, use RBFCalc3(). If
4329 you have general situation (NX-dimensional space, NY-dimensional function)
4330 you should use general, less efficient implementation RBFCalc().
4331 
4332 If you want to calculate function values many times, consider using
4333 RBFGridCalc2(), which is far more efficient than many subsequent calls to
4334 RBFCalc2().
4335 
4336 This function returns 0.0 when:
4337 * model is not initialized
4338 * NX<>2
4339  *NY<>1
4340 
4341 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4342  S - RBF model
4343  X0 - first coordinate, finite number
4344  X1 - second coordinate, finite number
4345 
4346 RESULT:
4347  value of the model or 0.0 (as defined above)
4348 
4349  -- ALGLIB --
4350  Copyright 13.12.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
4351 *************************************************************************/
4352 double rbfcalc2(const rbfmodel &s, const double x0, const double x1);
4353 
4354 
4355 /*************************************************************************
4356 This function calculates values of the RBF model in the given point.
4357 
4358 This function should be used when we have NY=1 (scalar function) and NX=3
4359 (3-dimensional space). If you have 2-dimensional space, use RBFCalc2(). If
4360 you have general situation (NX-dimensional space, NY-dimensional function)
4361 you should use general, less efficient implementation RBFCalc().
4362 
4363 This function returns 0.0 when:
4364 * model is not initialized
4365 * NX<>3
4366  *NY<>1
4367 
4368 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4369  S - RBF model
4370  X0 - first coordinate, finite number
4371  X1 - second coordinate, finite number
4372  X2 - third coordinate, finite number
4373 
4374 RESULT:
4375  value of the model or 0.0 (as defined above)
4376 
4377  -- ALGLIB --
4378  Copyright 13.12.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
4379 *************************************************************************/
4380 double rbfcalc3(const rbfmodel &s, const double x0, const double x1, const double x2);
4381 
4382 
4383 /*************************************************************************
4384 This function calculates values of the RBF model at the given point.
4385 
4386 This is general function which can be used for arbitrary NX (dimension of
4387 the space of arguments) and NY (dimension of the function itself). However
4388 when you have NY=1 you may find more convenient to use RBFCalc2() or
4389 RBFCalc3().
4390 
4391 This function returns 0.0 when model is not initialized.
4392 
4393 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4394  S - RBF model
4395  X - coordinates, array[NX].
4396  X may have more than NX elements, in this case only
4397  leading NX will be used.
4398 
4399 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4400  Y - function value, array[NY]. Y is out-parameter and
4401  reallocated after call to this function. In case you want
4402  to reuse previously allocated Y, you may use RBFCalcBuf(),
4403  which reallocates Y only when it is too small.
4404 
4405  -- ALGLIB --
4406  Copyright 13.12.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
4407 *************************************************************************/
4408 void rbfcalc(const rbfmodel &s, const real_1d_array &x, real_1d_array &y);
4409 
4410 
4411 /*************************************************************************
4412 This function calculates values of the RBF model at the given point.
4413 
4414 Same as RBFCalc(), but does not reallocate Y when in is large enough to
4415 store function values.
4416 
4417 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4418  S - RBF model
4419  X - coordinates, array[NX].
4420  X may have more than NX elements, in this case only
4421  leading NX will be used.
4422  Y - possibly preallocated array
4423 
4424 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4425  Y - function value, array[NY]. Y is not reallocated when it
4426  is larger than NY.
4427 
4428  -- ALGLIB --
4429  Copyright 13.12.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
4430 *************************************************************************/
4431 void rbfcalcbuf(const rbfmodel &s, const real_1d_array &x, real_1d_array &y);
4432 
4433 
4434 /*************************************************************************
4435 This function calculates values of the RBF model at the regular grid.
4436 
4437 Grid have N0*N1 points, with Point[I,J] = (X0[I], X1[J])
4438 
4439 This function returns 0.0 when:
4440 * model is not initialized
4441 * NX<>2
4442  *NY<>1
4443 
4444 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4445  S - RBF model
4446  X0 - array of grid nodes, first coordinates, array[N0]
4447  N0 - grid size (number of nodes) in the first dimension
4448  X1 - array of grid nodes, second coordinates, array[N1]
4449  N1 - grid size (number of nodes) in the second dimension
4450 
4451 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4452  Y - function values, array[N0,N1]. Y is out-variable and
4453  is reallocated by this function.
4454 
4455  -- ALGLIB --
4456  Copyright 13.12.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
4457 *************************************************************************/
4458 void rbfgridcalc2(const rbfmodel &s, const real_1d_array &x0, const ae_int_t n0, const real_1d_array &x1, const ae_int_t n1, real_2d_array &y);
4459 
4460 
4461 /*************************************************************************
4462 This function "unpacks" RBF model by extracting its coefficients.
4463 
4464 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4465  S - RBF model
4466 
4467 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4468  NX - dimensionality of argument
4469  NY - dimensionality of the target function
4470  XWR - model information, array[NC,NX+NY+1].
4471  One row of the array corresponds to one basis function:
4472  * first NX columns - coordinates of the center
4473  * next NY columns - weights, one per dimension of the
4474  function being modelled
4475  * last column - radius, same for all dimensions of
4476  the function being modelled
4477  NC - number of the centers
4478  V - polynomial term , array[NY,NX+1]. One row per one
4479  dimension of the function being modelled. First NX
4480  elements are linear coefficients, V[NX] is equal to the
4481  constant part.
4482 
4483  -- ALGLIB --
4484  Copyright 13.12.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
4485 *************************************************************************/
4486 void rbfunpack(const rbfmodel &s, ae_int_t &nx, ae_int_t &ny, real_2d_array &xwr, ae_int_t &nc, real_2d_array &v);
4487 
4488 /*************************************************************************
4489 This subroutine calculates the value of the bilinear or bicubic spline at
4490 the given point X.
4491 
4492 Input parameters:
4493  C - coefficients table.
4494  Built by BuildBilinearSpline or BuildBicubicSpline.
4495  X, Y- point
4496 
4497 Result:
4498  S(x,y)
4499 
4500  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
4501  Copyright 05.07.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
4502 *************************************************************************/
4503 double spline2dcalc(const spline2dinterpolant &c, const double x, const double y);
4504 
4505 
4506 /*************************************************************************
4507 This subroutine calculates the value of the bilinear or bicubic spline at
4508 the given point X and its derivatives.
4509 
4510 Input parameters:
4511  C - spline interpolant.
4512  X, Y- point
4513 
4514 Output parameters:
4515  F - S(x,y)
4516  FX - dS(x,y)/dX
4517  FY - dS(x,y)/dY
4518  FXY - d2S(x,y)/dXdY
4519 
4520  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
4521  Copyright 05.07.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
4522 *************************************************************************/
4523 void spline2ddiff(const spline2dinterpolant &c, const double x, const double y, double &f, double &fx, double &fy, double &fxy);
4524 
4525 
4526 /*************************************************************************
4527 This subroutine performs linear transformation of the spline argument.
4528 
4529 Input parameters:
4530  C - spline interpolant
4531  AX, BX - transformation coefficients: x = A*t + B
4532  AY, BY - transformation coefficients: y = A*u + B
4533 Result:
4534  C - transformed spline
4535 
4536  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
4537  Copyright 30.06.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
4538 *************************************************************************/
4539 void spline2dlintransxy(const spline2dinterpolant &c, const double ax, const double bx, const double ay, const double by);
4540 
4541 
4542 /*************************************************************************
4543 This subroutine performs linear transformation of the spline.
4544 
4545 Input parameters:
4546  C - spline interpolant.
4547  A, B- transformation coefficients: S2(x,y) = A*S(x,y) + B
4548 
4549 Output parameters:
4550  C - transformed spline
4551 
4552  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
4553  Copyright 30.06.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
4554 *************************************************************************/
4555 void spline2dlintransf(const spline2dinterpolant &c, const double a, const double b);
4556 
4557 
4558 /*************************************************************************
4559 This subroutine makes the copy of the spline model.
4560 
4561 Input parameters:
4562  C - spline interpolant
4563 
4564 Output parameters:
4565  CC - spline copy
4566 
4567  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
4568  Copyright 29.06.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
4569 *************************************************************************/
4570 void spline2dcopy(const spline2dinterpolant &c, spline2dinterpolant &cc);
4571 
4572 
4573 /*************************************************************************
4574 Bicubic spline resampling
4575 
4576 Input parameters:
4577  A - function values at the old grid,
4578  array[0..OldHeight-1, 0..OldWidth-1]
4579  OldHeight - old grid height, OldHeight>1
4580  OldWidth - old grid width, OldWidth>1
4581  NewHeight - new grid height, NewHeight>1
4582  NewWidth - new grid width, NewWidth>1
4583 
4584 Output parameters:
4585  B - function values at the new grid,
4586  array[0..NewHeight-1, 0..NewWidth-1]
4587 
4588  -- ALGLIB routine --
4589  15 May, 2007
4590  Copyright by Bochkanov Sergey
4591 *************************************************************************/
4592 void spline2dresamplebicubic(const real_2d_array &a, const ae_int_t oldheight, const ae_int_t oldwidth, real_2d_array &b, const ae_int_t newheight, const ae_int_t newwidth);
4593 
4594 
4595 /*************************************************************************
4596 Bilinear spline resampling
4597 
4598 Input parameters:
4599  A - function values at the old grid,
4600  array[0..OldHeight-1, 0..OldWidth-1]
4601  OldHeight - old grid height, OldHeight>1
4602  OldWidth - old grid width, OldWidth>1
4603  NewHeight - new grid height, NewHeight>1
4604  NewWidth - new grid width, NewWidth>1
4605 
4606 Output parameters:
4607  B - function values at the new grid,
4608  array[0..NewHeight-1, 0..NewWidth-1]
4609 
4610  -- ALGLIB routine --
4611  09.07.2007
4612  Copyright by Bochkanov Sergey
4613 *************************************************************************/
4614 void spline2dresamplebilinear(const real_2d_array &a, const ae_int_t oldheight, const ae_int_t oldwidth, real_2d_array &b, const ae_int_t newheight, const ae_int_t newwidth);
4615 
4616 
4617 /*************************************************************************
4618 This subroutine builds bilinear vector-valued spline.
4619 
4620 Input parameters:
4621  X - spline abscissas, array[0..N-1]
4622  Y - spline ordinates, array[0..M-1]
4623  F - function values, array[0..M*N*D-1]:
4624  * first D elements store D values at (X[0],Y[0])
4625  * next D elements store D values at (X[1],Y[0])
4626  * general form - D function values at (X[i],Y[j]) are stored
4627  at F[D*(J*N+I)...D*(J*N+I)+D-1].
4628  M,N - grid size, M>=2, N>=2
4629  D - vector dimension, D>=1
4630 
4631 Output parameters:
4632  C - spline interpolant
4633 
4634  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
4635  Copyright 16.04.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
4636 *************************************************************************/
4637 void spline2dbuildbilinearv(const real_1d_array &x, const ae_int_t n, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t m, const real_1d_array &f, const ae_int_t d, spline2dinterpolant &c);
4638 
4639 
4640 /*************************************************************************
4641 This subroutine builds bicubic vector-valued spline.
4642 
4643 Input parameters:
4644  X - spline abscissas, array[0..N-1]
4645  Y - spline ordinates, array[0..M-1]
4646  F - function values, array[0..M*N*D-1]:
4647  * first D elements store D values at (X[0],Y[0])
4648  * next D elements store D values at (X[1],Y[0])
4649  * general form - D function values at (X[i],Y[j]) are stored
4650  at F[D*(J*N+I)...D*(J*N+I)+D-1].
4651  M,N - grid size, M>=2, N>=2
4652  D - vector dimension, D>=1
4653 
4654 Output parameters:
4655  C - spline interpolant
4656 
4657  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
4658  Copyright 16.04.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
4659 *************************************************************************/
4660 void spline2dbuildbicubicv(const real_1d_array &x, const ae_int_t n, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t m, const real_1d_array &f, const ae_int_t d, spline2dinterpolant &c);
4661 
4662 
4663 /*************************************************************************
4664 This subroutine calculates bilinear or bicubic vector-valued spline at the
4665 given point (X,Y).
4666 
4667 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4668  C - spline interpolant.
4669  X, Y- point
4670  F - output buffer, possibly preallocated array. In case array size
4671  is large enough to store result, it is not reallocated. Array
4672  which is too short will be reallocated
4673 
4674 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4675  F - array[D] (or larger) which stores function values
4676 
4677  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
4678  Copyright 16.04.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
4679 *************************************************************************/
4680 void spline2dcalcvbuf(const spline2dinterpolant &c, const double x, const double y, real_1d_array &f);
4681 
4682 
4683 /*************************************************************************
4684 This subroutine calculates bilinear or bicubic vector-valued spline at the
4685 given point (X,Y).
4686 
4687 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4688  C - spline interpolant.
4689  X, Y- point
4690 
4691 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4692  F - array[D] which stores function values. F is out-parameter and
4693  it is reallocated after call to this function. In case you
4694  want to reuse previously allocated F, you may use
4695  Spline2DCalcVBuf(), which reallocates F only when it is too
4696  small.
4697 
4698  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
4699  Copyright 16.04.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
4700 *************************************************************************/
4701 void spline2dcalcv(const spline2dinterpolant &c, const double x, const double y, real_1d_array &f);
4702 
4703 
4704 /*************************************************************************
4705 This subroutine unpacks two-dimensional spline into the coefficients table
4706 
4707 Input parameters:
4708  C - spline interpolant.
4709 
4710 Result:
4711  M, N- grid size (x-axis and y-axis)
4712  D - number of components
4713  Tbl - coefficients table, unpacked format,
4714  D - components: [0..(N-1)*(M-1)*D-1, 0..19].
4715  For T=0..D-1 (component index), I = 0...N-2 (x index),
4716  J=0..M-2 (y index):
4717  K := T + I*D + J*D*(N-1)
4718 
4719  K-th row stores decomposition for T-th component of the
4720  vector-valued function
4721 
4722  Tbl[K,0] = X[i]
4723  Tbl[K,1] = X[i+1]
4724  Tbl[K,2] = Y[j]
4725  Tbl[K,3] = Y[j+1]
4726  Tbl[K,4] = C00
4727  Tbl[K,5] = C01
4728  Tbl[K,6] = C02
4729  Tbl[K,7] = C03
4730  Tbl[K,8] = C10
4731  Tbl[K,9] = C11
4732  ...
4733  Tbl[K,19] = C33
4734  On each grid square spline is equals to:
4735  S(x) = SUM(c[i,j]*(t^i)*(u^j), i=0..3, j=0..3)
4736  t = x-x[j]
4737  u = y-y[i]
4738 
4739  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
4740  Copyright 16.04.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
4741 *************************************************************************/
4742 void spline2dunpackv(const spline2dinterpolant &c, ae_int_t &m, ae_int_t &n, ae_int_t &d, real_2d_array &tbl);
4743 
4744 
4745 /*************************************************************************
4746 This subroutine was deprecated in ALGLIB 3.6.0
4747 
4748 We recommend you to switch to Spline2DBuildBilinearV(), which is more
4749 flexible and accepts its arguments in more convenient order.
4750 
4751  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
4752  Copyright 05.07.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
4753 *************************************************************************/
4754 void spline2dbuildbilinear(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_2d_array &f, const ae_int_t m, const ae_int_t n, spline2dinterpolant &c);
4755 
4756 
4757 /*************************************************************************
4758 This subroutine was deprecated in ALGLIB 3.6.0
4759 
4760 We recommend you to switch to Spline2DBuildBicubicV(), which is more
4761 flexible and accepts its arguments in more convenient order.
4762 
4763  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
4764  Copyright 05.07.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
4765 *************************************************************************/
4766 void spline2dbuildbicubic(const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &y, const real_2d_array &f, const ae_int_t m, const ae_int_t n, spline2dinterpolant &c);
4767 
4768 
4769 /*************************************************************************
4770 This subroutine was deprecated in ALGLIB 3.6.0
4771 
4772 We recommend you to switch to Spline2DUnpackV(), which is more flexible
4773 and accepts its arguments in more convenient order.
4774 
4775  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
4776  Copyright 29.06.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
4777 *************************************************************************/
4778 void spline2dunpack(const spline2dinterpolant &c, ae_int_t &m, ae_int_t &n, real_2d_array &tbl);
4779 
4780 /*************************************************************************
4781 This subroutine calculates the value of the trilinear or tricubic spline at
4782 the given point (X,Y,Z).
4783 
4784 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4785  C - coefficients table.
4786  Built by BuildBilinearSpline or BuildBicubicSpline.
4787  X, Y,
4788  Z - point
4789 
4790 Result:
4791  S(x,y,z)
4792 
4793  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
4794  Copyright 26.04.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
4795 *************************************************************************/
4796 double spline3dcalc(const spline3dinterpolant &c, const double x, const double y, const double z);
4797 
4798 
4799 /*************************************************************************
4800 This subroutine performs linear transformation of the spline argument.
4801 
4802 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4803  C - spline interpolant
4804  AX, BX - transformation coefficients: x = A*u + B
4805  AY, BY - transformation coefficients: y = A*v + B
4806  AZ, BZ - transformation coefficients: z = A*w + B
4807 
4808 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4809  C - transformed spline
4810 
4811  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
4812  Copyright 26.04.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
4813 *************************************************************************/
4814 void spline3dlintransxyz(const spline3dinterpolant &c, const double ax, const double bx, const double ay, const double by, const double az, const double bz);
4815 
4816 
4817 /*************************************************************************
4818 This subroutine performs linear transformation of the spline.
4819 
4820 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4821  C - spline interpolant.
4822  A, B- transformation coefficients: S2(x,y) = A*S(x,y,z) + B
4823 
4824 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4825  C - transformed spline
4826 
4827  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
4828  Copyright 26.04.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
4829 *************************************************************************/
4830 void spline3dlintransf(const spline3dinterpolant &c, const double a, const double b);
4831 
4832 
4833 /*************************************************************************
4834 Trilinear spline resampling
4835 
4836 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4837  A - array[0..OldXCount*OldYCount*OldZCount-1], function
4838  values at the old grid, :
4839  A[0] x=0,y=0,z=0
4840  A[1] x=1,y=0,z=0
4841  A[..] ...
4842  A[..] x=oldxcount-1,y=0,z=0
4843  A[..] x=0,y=1,z=0
4844  A[..] ...
4845  ...
4846  OldZCount - old Z-count, OldZCount>1
4847  OldYCount - old Y-count, OldYCount>1
4848  OldXCount - old X-count, OldXCount>1
4849  NewZCount - new Z-count, NewZCount>1
4850  NewYCount - new Y-count, NewYCount>1
4851  NewXCount - new X-count, NewXCount>1
4852 
4853 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4854  B - array[0..NewXCount*NewYCount*NewZCount-1], function
4855  values at the new grid:
4856  B[0] x=0,y=0,z=0
4857  B[1] x=1,y=0,z=0
4858  B[..] ...
4859  B[..] x=newxcount-1,y=0,z=0
4860  B[..] x=0,y=1,z=0
4861  B[..] ...
4862  ...
4863 
4864  -- ALGLIB routine --
4865  26.04.2012
4866  Copyright by Bochkanov Sergey
4867 *************************************************************************/
4868 void spline3dresampletrilinear(const real_1d_array &a, const ae_int_t oldzcount, const ae_int_t oldycount, const ae_int_t oldxcount, const ae_int_t newzcount, const ae_int_t newycount, const ae_int_t newxcount, real_1d_array &b);
4869 
4870 
4871 /*************************************************************************
4872 This subroutine builds trilinear vector-valued spline.
4873 
4874 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4875  X - spline abscissas, array[0..N-1]
4876  Y - spline ordinates, array[0..M-1]
4877  Z - spline applicates, array[0..L-1]
4878  F - function values, array[0..M*N*L*D-1]:
4879  * first D elements store D values at (X[0],Y[0],Z[0])
4880  * next D elements store D values at (X[1],Y[0],Z[0])
4881  * next D elements store D values at (X[2],Y[0],Z[0])
4882  * ...
4883  * next D elements store D values at (X[0],Y[1],Z[0])
4884  * next D elements store D values at (X[1],Y[1],Z[0])
4885  * next D elements store D values at (X[2],Y[1],Z[0])
4886  * ...
4887  * next D elements store D values at (X[0],Y[0],Z[1])
4888  * next D elements store D values at (X[1],Y[0],Z[1])
4889  * next D elements store D values at (X[2],Y[0],Z[1])
4890  * ...
4891  * general form - D function values at (X[i],Y[j]) are stored
4892  at F[D*(N*(M*K+J)+I)...D*(N*(M*K+J)+I)+D-1].
4893  M,N,
4894  L - grid size, M>=2, N>=2, L>=2
4895  D - vector dimension, D>=1
4896 
4897 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4898  C - spline interpolant
4899 
4900  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
4901  Copyright 26.04.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
4902 *************************************************************************/
4903 void spline3dbuildtrilinearv(const real_1d_array &x, const ae_int_t n, const real_1d_array &y, const ae_int_t m, const real_1d_array &z, const ae_int_t l, const real_1d_array &f, const ae_int_t d, spline3dinterpolant &c);
4904 
4905 
4906 /*************************************************************************
4907 This subroutine calculates bilinear or bicubic vector-valued spline at the
4908 given point (X,Y,Z).
4909 
4910 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4911  C - spline interpolant.
4912  X, Y,
4913  Z - point
4914  F - output buffer, possibly preallocated array. In case array size
4915  is large enough to store result, it is not reallocated. Array
4916  which is too short will be reallocated
4917 
4918 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4919  F - array[D] (or larger) which stores function values
4920 
4921  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
4922  Copyright 26.04.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
4923 *************************************************************************/
4924 void spline3dcalcvbuf(const spline3dinterpolant &c, const double x, const double y, const double z, real_1d_array &f);
4925 
4926 
4927 /*************************************************************************
4928 This subroutine calculates trilinear or tricubic vector-valued spline at the
4929 given point (X,Y,Z).
4930 
4931 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4932  C - spline interpolant.
4933  X, Y,
4934  Z - point
4935 
4936 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4937  F - array[D] which stores function values. F is out-parameter and
4938  it is reallocated after call to this function. In case you
4939  want to reuse previously allocated F, you may use
4940  Spline2DCalcVBuf(), which reallocates F only when it is too
4941  small.
4942 
4943  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
4944  Copyright 26.04.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
4945 *************************************************************************/
4946 void spline3dcalcv(const spline3dinterpolant &c, const double x, const double y, const double z, real_1d_array &f);
4947 
4948 
4949 /*************************************************************************
4950 This subroutine unpacks tri-dimensional spline into the coefficients table
4951 
4952 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4953  C - spline interpolant.
4954 
4955 Result:
4956  N - grid size (X)
4957  M - grid size (Y)
4958  L - grid size (Z)
4959  D - number of components
4960  SType- spline type. Currently, only one spline type is supported:
4961  trilinear spline, as indicated by SType=1.
4962  Tbl - spline coefficients: [0..(N-1)*(M-1)*(L-1)*D-1, 0..13].
4963  For T=0..D-1 (component index), I = 0...N-2 (x index),
4964  J=0..M-2 (y index), K=0..L-2 (z index):
4965  Q := T + I*D + J*D*(N-1) + K*D*(N-1)*(M-1),
4966 
4967  Q-th row stores decomposition for T-th component of the
4968  vector-valued function
4969 
4970  Tbl[Q,0] = X[i]
4971  Tbl[Q,1] = X[i+1]
4972  Tbl[Q,2] = Y[j]
4973  Tbl[Q,3] = Y[j+1]
4974  Tbl[Q,4] = Z[k]
4975  Tbl[Q,5] = Z[k+1]
4976 
4977  Tbl[Q,6] = C000
4978  Tbl[Q,7] = C100
4979  Tbl[Q,8] = C010
4980  Tbl[Q,9] = C110
4981  Tbl[Q,10]= C001
4982  Tbl[Q,11]= C101
4983  Tbl[Q,12]= C011
4984  Tbl[Q,13]= C111
4985  On each grid square spline is equals to:
4986  S(x) = SUM(c[i,j,k]*(x^i)*(y^j)*(z^k), i=0..1, j=0..1, k=0..1)
4987  t = x-x[j]
4988  u = y-y[i]
4989  v = z-z[k]
4990 
4991  NOTE: format of Tbl is given for SType=1. Future versions of
4992  ALGLIB can use different formats for different values of
4993  SType.
4994 
4995  -- ALGLIB PROJECT --
4996  Copyright 26.04.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
4997 *************************************************************************/
4998 void spline3dunpackv(const spline3dinterpolant &c, ae_int_t &n, ae_int_t &m, ae_int_t &l, ae_int_t &d, ae_int_t &stype, real_2d_array &tbl);
4999 }
5000

5003 // THIS SECTION CONTAINS COMPUTATIONAL CORE DECLARATIONS (FUNCTIONS)
5004 //

5136  double b,
